content:
2015
												How to start to describe one of the greatest games ever made? Well.. that's probably one of the reasons why I never did a review.Fallout has been, still is and probably will always be my favourite game (series) of all time. Ever since I first laid eyes on the game, somewhere back in 1997, I wish I could live in that same apocalyptic world. The perfect blend of a post-nuclear environment and 50's style, makes it unique and is the reason why I would pick this game over other great games like Baldurs Gate or Planescape Torment. Like many RPG's, you start of creating your character. Besides sex, there are no cosmetic changes. You do get to alter your skill points and perks. Depending how you create your character, you might get a whole different adventure, each time. Play as a female? You might get some unique conversations. Low intelligence? You can't even speak properly. The gameplay is real-time but turn-based in combat. You can do actions, based on your Action Points (AP) and so do your enemies. You can even aim on one of your enemies' parts; cripple his leg, shoot his head or bust his groin... it's all up to you. Your opponents often die in gruesome ways and there are tons of different weapons (melee, guns, heavy weapons, unarmed, energy), different armors for you to wear, tons of items and lots of (side) quests, so you won't get bored quickly.The writing in the game is exceptional. Most of the dialogue are interesting and often combined with a lot of (dark) humor. In my opinion, the humor is one of the best aspects of what describes Fallout, something Bethesda never got right (in Fallout 3). Only important NPC's have dialogue, which are often voiced by (former) celebrities like Dwight Schulz & Richard Dean Anderson. The narration is done by Ron Perlman, who rightfully became a Fallout Icon, over the years.The music, produced by Mark Morgan, is also excellent. It's without a doubt, one of the best soundtracks of any game. The experimental music creates the apocalyptic atmosphere, perfectly.  I highly recommend Fallout to every RPG lover out there. I could write a lot more about why I like Fallout but it all comes down to this: It's simply one of those games you have to play before you die.

content:
er 11, 2014
												Let me begin by noting that I was introduced to the Fallout series with Fallout 3, back in around 2009. I put hundreds of hours into the game between Xbox 360 and PC, and I found the world to be incredibly interesting and atmospheric. The RPG mechanics and depth were like something I had never before seen, being a teenager and my life having been more saturated with more casualized games such as Call of Duty.Up until I finished Fallout, Fallout 3 was my all-time favorite.But now that I've experienced Fallout, it's as if my standards have risen tenfold. It may seem weird given that the game is seventeen years old as of writing this review, but I can elaborate. This game has managed to deliver an experience like no other game I have ever played with simple isometric graphics, and most importantly, a surprisingly complex and mature narrative. The music, sounds, and intriguing -- but again, simple -- visuals create an ambient feeling of loneliness  throughout the wasteland. The soundtrack is hauntingly fitting, for example in Necropolis, a city of ghouls. The sound creepy churchbells amid a fine chord of a low key sends shivers down my spine.Adult themes similar to the philosophy of the Ubermensch, and existentialism are very prevalent as well.I love this game, and it has shown me the real potential of video games. Books present you with narrative. Films, with narrative, visualization, and sound. Video games, with narrative, visualization, sound, and interaction.10/10

number of helpful: 244 of 253 people (96%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2014
												Where to start with this game...'It's a classic' would be a good place to start, I guess. I have no problems say that from the outset. It's only taken me 15 years to get around to play original Fallout, but I can see without a shadow of a doubt why it's so highly regarded. Before you play this game make sure to download the Fallout Fixt mod, which is a very comprehensive community mod which fixes a lot of the bugs, and more importantly the resolution for modern monitors. Without this patch you'll more than likely experience a horrible rainbow pixalation effect during videos and gameplay. Anyway...Fallout is a turn-based RPG series which offers you various ways to tackle the game. Do you want to be a stealthy person, creeping around, pick pocketing your way to glory? Sure, why not! Do you want to be a smooth talking kinda guy who can talk his way in and out of trouble? Go on, be that guy! What about a bookworm who can use his brain to solve puzzles. Yup! And of course you can be a mix of all three, as well as a gun totting maniac! YEE-HAW!For my playthrough I used one of the pre-set characers (Albert) who was a Lawyer in a previous life and was set up with high charisma and speech skills. This opened up different dialogue trees throughout the game, which was nice. Anyway, I enjoyed this game - I enjoyed it a lot. The characters are great, the voice acting (while limited) was pretty nice (though it did give away who the 'important' characters were) and the story itself was pretty deep. The game starts, as always, with you the 'Vault Dweller' leaving your vault for the first time to explore the wastelands. You're tasked with bringing back a water chip to save your vault before everyone dies of thirst! There's a time limit to this, which (for me) cast a sense of urgency. Normally in Fallout games (Fallout 3 and New Vegas) I'm guilty of just going 'WHEEEEE' and exploring everywhere and not really caring what I'm doing. Yet in Fallout there's no time to explore, you've got to save lives!... if you want to. You see you don't NEED to save their lives, if you don't want to. In fact, you don't HAVE to do much in Fallout if you don't want to. It's not a narrow pathed experience, you can pretty much choose how you deal with the events in the game (and the end game cutscene will reflect on this at the end). A lot of games claim to be an open experience, and the actions you take reflecting on the game world, yet here's a game from 1997 which actually does that. I'm not sure it even heralds that fact that it does this. It just gets on with being a pretty damn good game. This brings me on to another aspect of the game - the many different branches of the game. People react to you differently depending on what you're wearing, what you're wielding, and what you're intelligence or charisma is. I find that amaizng now (in 2014), so I can only imagine how mindblowing it was back in 1997 when the game was released. The 'simple' graphics by today's standards shouldn't distract you from what is a very complex game. There's a lot going on under the hood of this game and at times perhaps too much.My eyes were really opened up to this towards the end of the game when I was struggling with killing a certain mob. I had went about it 'head on' and was killed a number of times. Yet, after a night's sleep I came back with a different approach, a more sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s approach and it was so much easier, and strangely satisfying. I had killed the guy and he had never even seen me.OK, sure the wastelands were plunged into another 100 years of nuclear fallout in the process, but hey... I KILLED THE GUY!However, even with the Fallout Fixt mod, the game can be prone to crash now and again. I'm not sure if it's the game's memory file getting too big or a conflict with Steam Overlay (wouldn't be a first), but towards the end of the game (and a lot of different quest outcomes) it started to become slightly unstable. So save REGULARLY!Which brings me on to another thing. This is an 'old school' game. It will not autosave for you, you must take control of your own save files. If you die you won't be taken back to the next/recent checkpoint... you'll have to load up from the last point you saved. This was the only thing I didn't like, but in the end I learned to live with it and it made me realise how pampered I had become as a gamer. I didn't have autosaves and 10 minute interval checkpoints when I was a kid and I still played games all the time back then. Yet, here I am as a grown man crying about dying and having to go back 20 minutes in the game because I had forgot to save... a lesson in life this game has given me.Also, this game is tough. REALLY tough. Depending on how you build your character, or which character you choose. You will die a lot.A lot.So in closing...If you're looking for an old school RPG experience than I'd recommend giving Fallout a try. I appreciate at time of writing they're no longer available on the Steam Store, or GOG, but hopefully they return one day, as they deserve to be played.

content:
0, 2015
												First of all, I'd like to note that this review is made by someone who has recently picked this game up - no nostalgia, only objectivity.The good:- Works well, zero crashes so far, one very minor bug (Shady Sands citizen was panicking over Tandi when she wasn't even gone yet). Zero compatibility issues - they have seriously taken GOOD care of the game when they made it available on Steam (I believe it's even running on some MS-DOS emulator but you don't notice a thing about that. Also it comes with some sort of resolution patch). Also, the game is very alt-tab friendly, you can alt-tab at any time without issues.- Very good story so far (10 hours in, so can't say everything about it, but so far it's been really good). This game is all about the dialogue. There's an amazing amount of text in this game - and many characters even have spoken dialogue and animations when you're talking to them. I'd go as far as saying the story is on pretty much the same level as 3 and NV so far, in my opinion - with better character building than NV, but more of an RPG touch than FO3 (but I know opinions differ greatly on this part, so take it with a grain of salt, and feel free to disagree).- This game has aged very well. I don't exactly know how to explain it, but I actually guess the closest analogy would be the old Pokémon games, gameplay-wise. Top-down view, grid based, turn-based combat. 2D games like this never really get old. You can try to make them look better but it'll just end up looking weird. - Price. This game is dirt cheap, I got it for about €1,50 during the summer sale.Neutral:- It's a hard game. It definitely is less forgiving than Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas. Don't be surprised to find a surprisingly large group of surprisingly strong raiders in your path at an early level. And even if you've played FO3 and FONV, you will more likely than not screw up your S.P.E.C.I.A.L. which means you'll have to start over and make a new character early on. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. and stats and perks are all rather complicated. I actually like it, though, despite having to start over because I have 1 strength and can't use my guns properly. The bad:-Resolution. It's locked to 4:3, and although the Steam version seemed to have some sort of Resolution patch and you can set it to your native resolution which lets you alt-tab quicker, you'll still have to either deal with pillarboxing or stretching. The textures also aren't of amazing resolutions, but that doesn't bother me much personally. The art style is amazing.- Might be hard to get hooked. Older games aren't for everyone and I understand that. I definitely love it though - and I only bought it during this summer sale. Never played it before. Hell, I was 3 years old when this game was released...Verdict:I personally think this game is easily worth the price they ask for it during a sale. It's old, but they took good care of it when they made it available on Steam. Give it a try!Edit - 18-1-2016I actually did end up playing this game a lot. However, I played it on my phone, in an emulator, so it still shows only 10.0 hours on Steam

y 22, 2014
												This is it. The Post-Apocalyptic RPG game that began a revolution and changed everything about the genre.PROS:- Well written story that will keep you interested until the end.- Charismatic and very well developed characters.- Karma and choice system (every positive and negative choice you made will count for the rest of the adventure).- Complex and complete interactive system and turn-based combat system.- The precise aiming system allows you to play strategically in battles (disable an enemy specific limb, blind it, stunt it, etc).- The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system gives the game an amazing way to improve the main protagonist skills/perks.- High quality 2D graphics with exceptional animations (for its time) that gives the characters/enemies great personality and a unique style.- Music that gets you into a decadent atmosfere on a wasted and post-apocalyptic Earth.- Excellent voice acting (many of those actors are highly recognized stars from the cinema and TV)- Innovative buying/selling and trading system.- Very accurate Point-and-click controls for pointing enemies, weapons, items, lockers, treasure chest, etc.CONS:- A pair of minor graphical glitches due to its age.If you love turn-based RPGs, you like the atmosphere from the Mad Max movies and you don't care to travel in time to the 90's (technologically speaking). this game will assure you hours of fun and satisfaction.My Score: 9/10Note: Played it on Windows XP - SP3

content:
6, 2015
												The original Fallout is hardly as accessible as its modern, 21st century sequels, however it is just as brilliant, if not more so, than the both of them put together. With fewer sidequests and a shorter main story, it isn't nearly as long as Bethesda's contributions to the series, however it more than makes up for that thanks to its incredible atmosphere and high levels of replayability.Now that I've gotten the necessary comparisons out of the way, I'd like to refrain from mentioning Fallout 3 and New Vegas from this point onwards. Yes, New Vegas ties into this game's story quite a fair bit more (considering 3 is something of an offshoot), however what it comes down to is those are two ultimately different games. What you're getting here is a turn-based strategy RPG that is dowright fantastic.I'll freely admit that the game didn't have me very intrigued when I first booted it up. The graphics were plain, the controls and interface decidedly confusing, and the mechanics unclear. However, after sticking through the game's beginning and unlocking both the world's and the story's fullest potentials, the brilliance of the experience washed over me; this is a game that is entirely dynamic. Every single action your player character takes has an effect in a far more dramatic way than most games, and a whole ton of things can vastly change based on how you respond to the challenges presented to you. I am entirely certain that after my first playthrough last week, I haven't even begun to experience the full depth of what this game has to offer.The battles in the game are initially unexciting, yet quickly become more unique. The "Action Points" system, while not entirely original, is still creative enough that so many years later it remains capable of keeping my attention and excitement at a high, something very rare of older RPGs (which are often plagued by interface and gameplay issues that could only be resolved later on with more powerful hardware and higher resolutions). My one gripe is the randomness of the critical hits found later on in the game; some seem to inflict so much damage to the player character that it is impossible not to be killed by them, even when at the level cap and using full power armor. This element of randomness is not appreciated given that it can instantly end the life of even the most well-prepared vault dweller. I also highly recommend you refrain from picking up the "Bloody Mess" perk, as it makes the gory death animations all the more satisfying when they do crop up.And make no mistake, they will crop up over the course of your playthrough, and when they do it is both grim, satisfying, and oddly hilarious. Watching a supermutant clutch at his stomach while guts spew out of them may at first leave you with a grimace on your face, and yet there's someting oddly humorous about the timing of the worm crawling out of his head when he's already been laying on the ground dead for a couple of seconds.Ultimately, it's the little details that make Fallout such an incredible game, especially given how they're able to factor into the overall experience. If you're willing to overlook an initially obtusely difficult set of game mechanics and UI elements, as well as some lacklustre graphics and annoying grammatical errors, what you'll unearth in the original Fallout is a dynamic RPG classic that is entirely deserving of its reputation as one of the greatest Western RPGs to have emerged from the lates 90s.

er 9, 2015
												An amazing game that laid the groundwork for an outstanding series. The first is still enjoyable today and you can see that not much has changed since 1997. Perks, SPECIAL, Pip-boy, manual targeting, character creation, leveling. It's all here. The only thing you won't find is real time combat because the game forces you into a turn-based system. That will take some time to get used to if you're a FPS player.The real shame is that most of the younger fans won't even give the first two games a go because of the graphics. The same can be said of the older players who refuse to accept the new games. I'm somewhere in the middle. I started out with Fallout 1 & 2, but I didn't become a hardcore fan until Fallout 3 and New Vegas. They all have their pros and cons, but the atmosphere and gameplay have remained mostly the same.There is a community of fans still developing bug fixes and resolution patches for this game. If you are a true fan then you owe it to yourself to play this. Might as well do it now while it still works on modern computers.

content:
er 19, 2016
												Fallout 1, the Holy Grail, the Michael Jackson, the ♥♥♥♥ing Switzerland of video games.My grandma told me to pick a gift, anything really, for my 10th birthday and by some cosmically fortuitous chain of events and decisions, I found Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game in the video game aisle to be the most to my liking. Of course I had no idea what a 'role playing game' was nor had anyone in my family ever wondered what PEGI 16 meant. Needless to say, with that purchase, grandma had probably affected my life the most since she decided to give birth to my father.Fallout is packed with (dark) humour, social commentary and pop-culture references. Honestly, I wouldn't get half the American idioms or jokes I do today... Playing it at a time the internet wasn't as ubiquitous, I completed dozens of playthroughs to explore all the endings, quests, dialogue options, nooks and crannies, lockboxes and special encounters. The fact I didn't get bored is an endorsement in itself. I still remember how eerie it felt arriving at the Brotherhood, figuring out The Glow or encountering a patrol of super mutants for the first time. I was quite immersed and instead of thinking 'I'll just reload a save', got genuinely scared of what would happen if the mutant with the minigun opened fire. (I'd be criticalled for 583 damage, having my head and arms torn off) The sense of free exploration and consequences of your actions you get when strolling too far west from the starting area and getting killed by super scary monsters is something most of today's RPGs are missing with their linear film-like narratives, tutorial quests and whatnot. Save game management is quite important, it may easily happen you'll lose a couple of hours of gameplay or that an earlier decision has narrowed your choices significantly or that you've managed to paint yourself into a corner bug-wise.The soundtrack is great, the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system is great. Everything about it is great.I know this was 90% nostalgia, but I don't care.

number of helpful: 93 of 103 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2013
												     The original Fallout is a turn based RPG.  You create, control, and level up a single character, but you can also recruit others to your cause.  Unfortunately, followers can only have their weapons upgraded in the vanilla version of the game; however, with Fallout Fixit, they can level up and have the armor upgraded like in Fallout 2.     The game is short by RPG standards -only about 20 hours- but a low price should offset such concerns.  Furthermore, the time that you do spend in game is what I refer to as quality game play time;  in other words, there are no boring and repetive quests or other filler content that increases game time without really adding to the game.  Your time spent in Fallout 1 will be filled with lighting raiders on fire, taking headshots on super mutants, performing unique side quests, and collecting all manner of new and destructive weapons.     Unfortunately, Fallout 1 is not without it's flaws.  For one, the grapics are quite dated.  If beautiful graphics are a requirement for you, then you might want to skip this one.  Second, the inventory interface is rather clunky.  Such an interface would probably be considered unacceptable by modern standards, but it's not bad enough that it should destroy your ability to enjoy the game.  Finally, there are other small concerns (such as the inability to move followers that get in your way).  However, these are mostly fixed by the Fallout Fixit patch.  In fact, I highly recommend this patch (see the Steam Forums or do a Google search).  It restores some cut content, makes followers more useful/powerfull, includes the high resolution patch, and much more.     The game may be showing its age when it comes to graphics and a clunky interface, but RPG lovers willing to look past these flaws will find a diamond in the rough.  The RPG mechanics are quite satisfying and the world and atmosphere are so captivating, that even after 15 years and 4 other Fallout games, fans still can't get enough.

content:
er 25, 2013
												One of the first real modern cRPGs and part of the late 90s cRPG revival which is now in old school territory. This single character classless turn-based isometric RPG is still considered a high-water mark of the genre. The quests can be completed multiple ways using multiple character types. The game is loaded with skill checks.  Combat, speech, and stealth paths are all viable and supported heavily right through to the end game. Replays are a must in order to witness this amount of depth.  The writing and voice acting is top notch and the dark/humorous post nuclear setting in an alternate retro-future timeline as imagined by 1950s America is something SPECIAL.  Perhaps the most controversial element is the time limit but I'd argue it adds a good sense of urgency lacking in nearly every other RPG. Truth is it's very generous and can be extended.  For those of us who played the game many times, it's actually moot since the game can be completed in 30 minutes if you know what you are doing.

content:
y 31
												It's year 2017 and I completed "Fallout" for the first time. A post-apocalyptic turn based RPG. You need to help your nuclear vault community by finding a water purifying chip, otherwise they are doomed. Find your way in a desert world full of mystery, monsters and fighting factions. The game is really enjoyable if you like classic RPGs and don't mind older graphics.PROS:- Graphics is oldish today, but it sets the mood really well and is quite nice.- Atmospheric music.- Non linear plot with multiple ways to achieve goals and multiple outcomes.- Good story.- Character development impacts your fighting strategies and dialogue options.- Multiple factions to join, work with and fight.- Multiple weapons.MEH:- Some companions may join you and help you, but you can barely manage them and they may be a nuissance.- Interface is oldish and may be a little annoying at times (but only a little). By the way: you can enter numbers from keyboard when you trade with someone, you don't need to set the price with mouse (which is slow).- There is a huge random factor in combat, so you need to save often. Because even if odds are in your favor you may lose.CONS:- None :)Conclusion: I highly recommend this classic RPG with satisfying story and immersive post-apocalyptic mood.GAMEPLAY 8/10GRAPHICS 8/10AUDIO 8/10STORY 10/10

content:
8, 2016
 Please consider that I am slightly biased, as I just finished the game, five minutes ago. Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing game is amazing. No Fallout game has gotten as much of an emotional responce as the original.The locations are great, every location has it's own charm.Some characters are really memorable and cool, such as Harold, in Old Town.The turn-based combat system allows for actual strategy, though sometimes that goes out the window with Criticals.The fact that this game is so unforgiving makes struggling through that more rewarding,Call me a monster, but shooting your raider-attackers as they flee for their lives is strangely satisfying.I'm, personally, HEAVILY against time-limits. I'm in the game to see the sights, do the quests, and go at my own pace. (The game lets you do that once you've collected the water chip.) For the Fallout fans... The only negative thing I can say about this game, is comparing it to Fallout 4 really shows what's happened to the series. Depressing.Super Mutants aren't one-note brutes! They're organized, powerful, sometimes intelligent! The Brotherhood of Steel does their DAMN JOBPower Armour is *very* rare but it's very, very effective. With it, pistols, SMGs, even Miniguns have 0 effect on the wearer.No quest markers, not a bad thing, just a heads-up. Gods, I love this game.

content:
8, 2015
												Fallout 2 is the better game. The mixture of a big world, plenty of unique NPCs, many side quests, complex dialogue trees, and a nice amount of adult-themed humor and social critique are still unsurpassed.However, Fallout 1 just oozes that dark, gritty atmosphere. The future happens to be a grim place. The awesome  atmospheric soundtrack, the memorable characters you meet (often with a well-aimed critical shot to the crotch), and the broken towns and nuclear wastelands you visit during your journey through southern California all contribute to that special post-apocalyptic "feel" in ways that Fallout 2 can't quite copy, and Fallout 3 is totally unable to achieve. This CRPG from 1997 was made for PC gamers who prefer good dialogues, adult themes, an immersive experience, and a deep role-playing system.

content:
ber 19, 2016
												Believe it or not I made it all the way to 2016 without playing a Fallout game but boy am I glad I decided to start at the beginning. Nearly 20 years after its initial release and this game still holds up. Like a fine wine or some scrumptious cheese it has indeed aged quite nicely. Although, I understand that this game may not be to everyones taste - much like that of the aformentioned wine and cheese. The dated graphics (and no, mods can't fix that) as well as the turn based combat may be an instant turn off for some people but I urge you not to judge this game at face value. This game is genuinly engrossing if you just take the time to sit down and immerse yourself in this masterfully crafted world. Your time will not be wasted. You can be what you want right from the start of the game you have the option of creating a completely customised character, which I strongly recommend. Even before the game has begun the entirely open ended adventure is presented to you. You have full command over the person YOU want to be. Do you want to be an honest man of the people? Skilled with a number of weapons, but only willing to draw on those who deserve it. A vicious psychopath? One who detests guns and craves blood with his bare hands. A free peace loving care free individual? Whom always uses their medicinal substances with the utmost responsibility of course. You can even play as a mentally damaged individual, struggling through day to day life and conversation in the wasteland if you so choose. Your adventure is unique.Another thing, the writing in this game is superb, and at times, downright hilarious. Just be prepared to do a lot of reading. In essence this game is a text based adventure with an isometric skin on the top. Which brings me to the animations, which are oozing with detail. Holstering weapons, enemy attacks and death animations in particular which always seem bring a smile to my face - although probably for the wrong reasons. Not to fear, it isn't just silent reading with some fancy moving pictures thrown in to keep you entertained. The audio is a real treat. Each settlement you encounter throughout your journey across the wasteland plays host to a unique soundtrack that does wonders for world building. On top of this, some key NPCs have completely voiced dialouge. In a game of this age a cringe fest of audio is to be expected yet you are pleastly surprised when you are treated to an atmospheric soundtrack and wide variety of  excellent voice acting. Seriously, wandering into a new settlement for the first time and being blown away by the diversity in the voiced dialouge is quite entertaining. I could go on about the writing of the questlines and dialouge or numerous amusing allusions to various pop culture icons...But I won't. Becuase this truely open ended experience is just that. An experience. To go on any longer threatens to ruin the magic of the unknown and adventure that is Fallout.

number of helpful: 46 of 49 people (94%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
, 2015
												The Fallout world is my favourite fictional world, period. The lore is deep and intelligent, and packed full of interesting characters, concepts, and secrets for the player to learn about and discover. The debut Fallout game itself is a classic RPG by an measure, and one of the best RPGs of the 90s. While not as accessible as the most recent games in the series, Fallout doesn't lack charm and depth, and for those with the patience to tackle a game that's part classic RPG, part adventure game, it holds a wealth of wonderful fiction to discover. However, As much as it was a great achievement in terms of storytelling and world-building, it is a product of its time and thus suffers from some of the problems that plagued both the aforementioned genres in the 90s: clunky UI, an isometric camera that often impedes movement and blocks items and people, combat that relies utterly on chance with little skill involved, unforgiving difficulty for beginner characters, and - worst of all IMO - illogical solutions to problems that can leave unwitting players frustrated. You didn't think to use a radio on that one particular computer? Too bad, buddy, you're stuckFallout 2 is bigger, streamlines some of the technical issues and irons out some unintuitive features, but I think that this is the superior game when it comes to plot, tone, and narrative. The fantastic voice acting from some great performers coupled with the driving storyline really draws you in and makes you feel like there is something real at stake. The narrative and the world really are the game's strongest features. Complaints aside, I do recommend that any fan of the Fallout series commit some time to discovering this game, and delving deeper into the world of Fallout.

number of helpful: 52 of 59 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
er 20, 2016
nukes-viewHi all, nukes here.Fallout is a isometric, free roam, turn based (combat only), role playing game. I found to be a great game, although yes it is dated and hasn't aged well in graphical terms. The content and story I found great and enjoyed every minute.Considering its release date of 1997, it still is overall a brilliant game, anyway let me explain myself.The Game PlayBefore you start on your journey you are able to create a character. With various options and choices related to a point based skill system, that is also commonly used in the later fallout games.After character creation you are put in the shoes of a dweller of vault 13, sent out into the desolate wastelands save the vault.DifficultyThe difficulty of the game is, let's say unforgiving if you are unprepared. I must admit I died quite a few times walking into places I didn't belong or starting fights with bigger stronger characters.Hopefully you will find your demises just as funny as I found mine. (Save regularly)In the options you can set the difficulty of the games combat system in your favour. I left this at a default state to enjoy the game as it was intended.Controls & InterfaceI cannot say I am a fan of the control system but for the age of the game I can see why the controls were done in this way. Although once you get the hang of them it become straight forward.First of all they are a little hard to get use to as there is no definitive tutorial and is based on a left click and right click system with a hold function, the keyboard is not necessarily required.The inventory system is simple and works well, although for future games I hope to see much more functionality. It uses a drag and drop system with hold click as well.AchievementsThis game has no steam achievements. Which I think increased my enjoyment of the game.StoryThe plot of the story I found to be great as it gets you stuck in straight away. By giving you a lengthy time limited quest to save the people of your vault right away gives you a sense of urgency. I found the main quests and side quests fun which kept me coming back for more. The ending I found was very fitting and I hope anyone who plays through the game enjoys it as much as me.Combat System The combat is turn based, with each turn you have action points (AP) relating to how much agility you have including traits that can give you extra AP's for a turn. What you do in combat is up to you although everything will have a cost of AP you could if you fancy shoot your own allies or miss the enemy and accidently vaporise your ally.Skills & TraitsEvery time you level up you get to put points into certain skills and every three levels you can choose a trait, not counting the two you can choose on character creation.I chose traits and skills on how I wanted to build my character some of them you will find useful and some you won't. Try saving before hand to test ones out. So you're not stuck with something you don't find useful.Sounds  & EffectsDue to the age of the game the sounds are still pretty decent and fitting for the wasteland environment.GraphicsThe graphics although dated for game that came out in 1997 are still pretty good, although trying to find items on the floor can be a little challenging.Cut ScenesThe cut scenes, death scenes and endings are great, although dated now I still enjoyed them.Humour & TriviaI liked the games humour and spent a good few hours on the fandom wiki. I liked that Dogmeat is a reference to Madmax 2 which was completely unexpected.Woof!Game UtilitiesBe careful the game does not offer a auto save function so any vault dweller must be extra careful before taking important actions. Whether it is stealing from or killing an innocent civilian or starting a fight with a super mutant.You may end up quite dead.MultiplayerThis game is single player only and does not contain any multiplayer. Although you can hire non player characters (NPC's) as mercenaries to follow you around on missions. Which is highly useful so long as you don't accidentally shoot them instead of your enemies. Bugs - ImportantUnfortunately fallout has a tendency to crash at random times which I presume is based on the fact it was not meant to run on newer versions of windows.So vault dwellers I recommend you save regularly.Also be wary of tabbing out, many have reported not being able to get back into the game although the game seems minimised. This not necessarily true hover down in the left hand corner above the task bar and you will find an invisible box click it and should maximise fallout.ConclusionOverall I found this game very fun to play, par the minor crashes and issues with tabbing out. This game may be dated by modern game standards.I personally think this is a fantastic game and hopefully never forgotten, if you ever have the chance to play and you have played any of the fallout games I strongly recommend you play this one.Hope I helped.ηυĸєΜ266

er 3, 2013
												The Fallout Series has always been a favorite of mine. When I first played Fallout 1, I sucked so much at it. (Although this can be traced back to the fact that I actually didn't play very many turn based games) At times I would stop playing due to its difficulty, but after a while you get the hang of it. My suggestion would be if you like old school turn based RPG's that can be a challenge, definitely buy this game. The story is fantastic and the gameplay is fun yet challenging. The only complaints would be the few bugs here and there as well as the ending. There's nothing wrong with the ending itself, its just that after you beat the game you cannot continue with your save. Kinda sucks, but other than that the game is flawless. It will always be one of my favorite games of all time.

y 14, 2016
												Legendary role-playing game with very sophisticated turn-based battle system and supreme universe of dark age after nuclear war.And, finally, it is working properly on Steam, with convenient High Res fix, which was really needed!I remember buying the game 2 years back, and it was without that fix back then. So it was lost for many players, until some wizardry wind (probably from GOG galaxy), turned this game alive once more. Now it is more stable and reliable on Windows 7 and upper, than Fallout 3.Another fix I've noticed from my previous experience - they cut all kids from the game, so you can't kill them and become child killer now. Good thing, even if it is a restriction for somebody role-playing a maniac. There are too many of them around us already.What else can I say? The game is a must-have for any real fan of true role-playing games and tough turn-based fights. It is much better than all three new Shadowrun games, in scenario, in combats, and overall complexity.Multiplicity of choices on every step, and various consequences for every step you'll made. Very clever opponents, even overpowered for modern casual players. And that unforgettable feeling of frontier, with that leather armor from old Mad Max on your shoulders.An essence of western role-playing games. 10/10 mark, as goes with all golden bars of gaming in my collection.

												An amazing isometric RPG with a post-apocalyptic theme, Fallout has become one of my go-to games when in need of a serious RPG nostalgia trip. The series is my favourite series of all time, for good reasons.Pro's:+ Amazing depth, with interesting skills and perks, making for awesome character development.+ Fantastic story with multiple endings, and long/short ways to achieve those endings.+ Engrossing world with interesting characters, quests and background stories to really set the mood of the wasteland.+ Steam edition includes some nice UI touches with the widescreen mod built-in.+ Combinations of points 1 & 2 make for exceptional replayability with different characters each time.Con's:- Unforgiving (Not really a con to me as I enjoy the challenge) Daunting for new RPG players unfamiliar with the genre.- Still some minor bugs present throughout the years.- Some redundant perks that can seem good at first pick and then become useless.

content:
15, 2016
												War. War never changes.The Romans waged war to gather slaves and wealth. Spain built an empire from its lust for gold and territory. Hitler shaped a battered Germany into an economic superpower.But war never changes.In the 21st century, war was still waged over the resources that could be acquired. Only this time, the spoils of war were also its weapons: Petroleum and Uranium. For these resources, China would invade Alaska, the US would annex Canada, and the European Commonwealth would dissolve into quarreling, bickering nation-states, bent on controlling the last remaining resources on Earth.In 2077, the storm of world war had come again. In two brief hours, most of the planet was reduced to cinders. And from the ashes of nuclear devastation, a new civilization would struggle to arise.A few were able to reach the relative safety of the large underground Vaults. Your family was part of that group that entered Vault Thirteen. Imprisoned safely behind the large Vault door, under a mountain of stone, a generation has lived without knowledge of the outside world.Life in the Vault is about to change.

content:
er 19, 2015
												Very few games do what Fallout 1 does.Very few games let you play the entire campaign without firing a single shot or killing a single creature. Fallout 1 doesVery few games manage to tell a meaningful dark story while also making you laugh at jokes and references. Fallout 1 does.Very few games capture the table top rpg experience without losing much during the transition to video game. Fallout 1 does.Very few games provide a level of replayability that the experience is still exciting years later. Fallout 1 does.Fallout 1 gets so many things right it quickly becomes clear why it overshadowed the very material it was based upon. It has so many short comings and problems and graphically it doesn't stand the test of time as well as other games but to the individual who is willing to take the time to learn the systems and get involved in the world the game offers up will have the potential to lose many hours and restful sleeps as you always want to go on one more adventure or try something in a different way.The game is a true role playing experience, to enjoy it for what it offers you need to become less of a power gamer and instead focus on rolling with the punches and taking leaps of faith as you forge the story and personality of your character. You need to become the person who enjoys reading text and develop a love for turnbased combat. Fallout 1 isn't for everyone and coming here from fallout 3-current is going to be jarring and difficult for some, and that is alright, but it is worth the money and time to at least give it a chance as the game rewards you with an experience no other game really has matched.The steam version of this game runs fine on modern hardware with little to no setup however installing the fan made community patch 'Fallout Fixit" will make your experience far less buggy, crash prone, balanced, and clean.I could not recommend fallout enough and it is easily in my top ten games of all time.

How hard can it be?"*while travelling to Vault 15*You stumbled into a pack of radscorpions"Ok I'll just kill them with this 10MM pistol"4 turns later I'm dead10/1011/07/16I'm going to write an *actual* review now. Fallout is an amazing example of an RPG. It sets up the atmosphere and look of a world scorched by nuclear fire amazingly. The game hits the "Post apocalyptic desert" right on the head. There's no plant life, water, anything of that sort. As a first in a series it is a good solid foundation for the next game in the series, Fallout 2. You are able to completely design your character, there's no backstory of your character given to you. (I'm looking at you Fallout 4) All the game says to you is: You live in a Vault. That's it. You can be the second coming of Jesus, or Satan incarnate. Also most dialouge options will follow a forumla and you'll be given 4 or sometimes more choices. These are:Yes, I will do ____No, I will not do ____Say something that pisses the NPC off, failing the quest.Say something that causes the Super Mutants to find your Vault more easily. (Yes I borrowed this from another review but it works so)This game is the second best in the series, bested by only it's sequel Fallout 2. It is truly a 10/10 game.

I've put a lot of hours into the other games. 3, NV, 4. And that's because for as great or terrible as they may be, I'm still left with a grumbling stomach. Really, that's why I recommend this game, because I'm sure that after one playthrough you'll feel full for a while and want to reflect on the meal you've just had, and not go back for seconds the second you finished it like with many other games.

number of helpful: 15 of 15 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 17, 2015
												Summary: Post-apocalyptic isometric turn-based RPGMultiplayer: NoCompletion: 20 hrsCards: NoCloud: YesYep. Still good after nearly 20 years. Fallout presents a world that has been devastated by the nuclear apocalypse. Underground containment facilities known as Vaults house the last remnants of humanity and the battle for survival has begun.Fallout uses a hex-grid isometric turn-based combat system. Combat blends seamlessly into its map system, much like games made with the Infinity Engine. It's a fun system, but there's only one problem I have with it - everything takes its turn one at a time. This becomes problematic when there's 20 things on the screen and you spend more time watching the computer make its moves compared to your single move. If there was a way for all NPCs to take their turn at the same time, that'd be a vast improvement. For the most part the game aged well. The steam version includes tweaks to help it run on modern systems, which helps immensely. The chat interface is still rather confining, but you get used to it. There's a lot of freedom in Fallout.  I have an unhealthy obsession with making and optimizing new characters to suit my play style. You can gun down friend and foe alike, devastate entire towns, and still complete the game. Even though there doesn't feel like there's a lot of quests, Fallout actually takes a fair amount of time to get through without speedrunning. But I can sum up why we love the game - Power Armor. After mowing down hordes of raiders while wearing naught but leather, it's satisfying to procure the ultimate badass protection in the land. Oh yessss. And you can reinforce it for good measure!Fallout will likely remain among my favorites for years to come. Being able to create new character concepts and impose new challenges upon myself, I will happily play the game yet again in ten more years. I rate this a 9/10.

												Hey folks! thought I would give Fallout a quick little review rundown. Over the last few days, I have done nothing but play this game. It really kept me wanting to get to the end of it and see what had happened to the settlements I had worked with. What works about 'Fallout' is it starts off with a time limit for you to get a water chip so it starts off seeming really restrictive, Not soon after did I realize that went away when you get the water chip and I must have had around 1,000,000 random encounters through the entire game (obviously I'm exaggerating) Iook, I loved this game but I had a ton of issues with crashes and irritation from just how hard the game really was (not a bad thing at all:P) 'Fallout' is a game like no other and is different from other Fallout games for countless reasons. Looking back at it now for a 1997 game, what you see is what you get and what you get is awesome. Another thing that works in the game is the story and dialogue goes so deep it's ridiculous, you can tell how many playstyles the developers expected different people to go through. And high praise needs to go to the scary ♥♥♥ soundtrack for the game. Listenening to the Boneyard and Necropolis music in this just made me neither cry of fright. It's done so well. Just be warned. You might not exactly enjoy this game, it's an old game and takes some getting used to but for me well I play old games all the time! Fallout is near perfect and future Fallout games should pay more attention to this one.

content:
er 27, 2012
												Fallout is one of those games that you just never forget. It's world and storyline just sticks with you and becomes part of the basis on which you judge all other games. It is a game that changes all of your preconceptions of how an RPG should play out. What is good? What is evil? Fallout is a game that ask you what is most important, the intention to do good or the end result being good despite the intention. Nothing is simply black and white and nobody's actions are simple.Fallout starts out simple enough, you are a Vault Dweller. Living beneath the earth sheltered from the nuclear devastation above you have never had to worry much about anything until now. Your vault's water chip has failed and there is no spare on hand so the Overseer, the supreme ruler of the vault, nominates you to be the first person ever to leave vault and go forth and procure a new water chip.As you leave the vault and begin to travel the outside wasteland you quickly find that you are not the only survivors in this post-apocalyptic world. Other vaults and just plain resourceful people have managed to build communities and the world is rebuilding, for the most part. As you travel around to these communities and their inhabitants question your sanity as you question them about vault's and water chips you quickly realize that a greater threat looms in the horizon, one that neither you nor your vault can ignore for long.Fallout is an isometric with turn based combat, you can recruit companions along the way but the lack of any direct control over them makes them rather suicidal, or in the case of the ones using burst weapons, makes you rather suicidal. The combat is not particularly brilliant but works well enough that you won't get annoyed with it until many playthroughs in.You advance your character using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system, "Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Luck", and have a multitude of skills to help you along the way. Many of the skills are non-combat related and having high skills or stats can open up new conversation options and previously unseen ways of completing quests and objectives. Most notable is the low intelligence options. While having a low intelligence, and thus very low skills, will close off most of the normal options for you throughout the game it will also create unique dialog and options with nearly every character in the game making it an experience worth a playthrough all on it's own.Fallout's open and extremely non-linear world, it's superb writing and storyline, it's strong and memorable characters and it's unique take on morality makes it one of the best gaming experiences around, worth a play even today.It is a game that challenges your perceptions of grey and your perceptions of RPG's. As you travel through the wasteland you'll find greed, hatred, joy and sadness and you'll get to chose to help or hurt, just not always in the way you expected. You'll see things of pleasure and things of pain and you'll get to choose your own way through every challenge as you brave the wilderness of a post-apocalyptic world.In the end you will find that your ally is truth, your enemy is a desire to do good and your only hope for victory is tragedy...Buy it if you don't already own it. Play it if you do.

content:
er 31, 2013
												This is it. The beginning of the Fallout franchise. And what a beginning it was.Fallout (along with its sequel, Fallout 2, and the spinoff Fallout Tactics to an extent) is an isometric, turn-based cRPG. The main premise of Fallout is surviving in a heavily destroyed post-apocalyptic world ravaged by nuclear warfare. The post-apocalyptic setting of Fallout is influenced greatly by other forefathers of the post-apocalyptic genre in fiction, most notably the Mad Max films and Wasteland, the video game. Interestingly enough, Fallout established itself as an immense influence in the genre not long after the game's release, becoming an iconic flagship of the setting for years to come.The game uses a top-down perspective, and characters can move in six directions, within a hexagonal grid. Combat in the game is based on using this grid-based movement system to move your character around the battlefield, and attack/do other actions using action points. Each character is granted a limited number of action points (AP) per turn, and when their AP runs out, the turn ends, and the enemy party is allowed to act. Fallout's combat system places a large emphasis on planning and forethought, and also on smart and informed character building. Fallout is apparently well-known for its difficulty, and although I disagree with it being a particularly hard game, it may still be difficult for new players to get into because of the depth of the gameplay mechanics, and how relatively badly they're documented within the game itself. While I by no means want to imply that Fallout is cryptic, there are still plenty of things within this game that are tougher for new players to grasp. The game has no real tutorial, and some of the menus are cluster♥♥♥♥s to navigate, resulting in the game taking a while to learn how to play fluently.Albeit the combat of the game is relatively simple, (you can move, open menus/your inventory, attack, and do aimed attacks) the combat system is extremely good, and also incredibly satisfying, especially when it goes your way. Probably one of the best I've ever experienced in a cRPG, in fact. The combat does exactly what it is supposed to do and does it very well, and can even be exploited by players that were careful with their character's build to get great benefits, like being able to get immense criticals by aiming at specific enemy body parts (Rat was critically hit in the eyes for 666 hit points, blinding the unlucky creature. Rat was killed.) or being able to attack more times per turn by stacking AP properly. Fallout encourages powergaming heavily, and greatly rewards players that are experienced in the game.Fallout's combat is not without its flaws, however. There is at times a frustratingly heavy emphasis on RNG, the best example of which being how the player's chance to hit is always capped at 95%, regardless of their skill in the weapon/other factors. This leaves a window for the player to be able to miss, no matter how ridiculous the circumstances. There is also a rather obscure critical failure mechanic, where if your skill in something is too low (or even if it's high enough) you'll ♥♥♥♥ up on that specific action so hard that you'll break what you're trying to do. Sometimes in combat you'll lose a turn or even break your weapon. While this mechanic was probably meant to make the gameplay more dynamic, it only truly results in making it more frustrating for players, and usually leads to players saving exceedingly often to pad themselves against the game's inherent unpredictability.The game is relatively short by RPG standards, usually lasting around 20-30 hours for most (non-completionist) players, but has an enormous amount of content. While a skilled and dedicated player can beat the game in under an hour if they wish to, there is nothing stopping you from tackling on Fallout's great many side-quests and encounters. There is a heavy emphasis in this game on quality over quality, and it shows, as every event in the game is unique and there is pretty much no copy-pasted filler content.All in all, Fallout is an iconic RPG, in great part shaping both the genres of modern post-apocalyptic fiction, and that of role-playing games, and is heavily befitting of being called a true classic. If you consider yourself a fan of role-playing games and haven't played this, you seriously need to. If you consider yourself a fan of Fallout games and haven't played this, you seriously need to get out.The darkness of the afterlife is all that awaits you now. May you find more peace in that world than you found in this one...

content:
12
												It almost feels blasphemous to say anything bad about a classic like this that people have always held in such high regard but the truth us its A decent enough game but definitely overrated and not just because its mechanics show their age. The visuals suck and the interface is clunky and cumbersome. It can be easy to miss items/NPCs/doors because of how they blend into the background share the same sprite as others or just The isometric view just being awkward . Locations can feel plain and dull. Companions are just an annoyance to trap you in a corner or shoot you in the back. Every settlement is completely anal about you putting your weapon away. Conversation checks are invisible (speech checks etc) so you won't know when you use them. Most skills are next to useless. It always felt like I had more to sell than shopkeepers could ever buy off me. There are some good and comical lines in conversations. Combat is Turn based fun and bloody/gore and critting super mutants in the eyes with a good plasma rifle never got old. V.A.T.S lets you aim for the eyes or private areas. Random encounters are dangerous to fun or funny or WTF lol. You can sometimes play multiples ways doing some quests such guns blazing or use stealth or tricks but these are not always obvious such as wearing robes for disguise or using the radio on force field signals. The setting feels right for what it is. The Voiced NPC's are voiced well. People recommend  you to save alot and this is true. But is this a good thing ? Punishments can be severe and situations do happen like a towns guards will try to kill you and your find out another time it was because something like you didn't put your gun away or killing someone in self defence can cause a town to be hostile/or ban you. Some people will like this but most people are just going to reload. Choices are good when done well. Later Fallout games you take responsibility for your actions still but give you more options for the aftermath. Alot of Fans of later Fallout games will naturally be interested to see what the earlier games are like. While you may love or hate them they are difficult to compare as they are very different. The biggest thing being perhaps an Isometric vs a FPS Style and for me I prefer the FPS style, I find it alot more immersive and fun too. One thing that could be shared is the dialogue. You have the voiced conversations and the choices of what to say be polite or not or funny.(Fallout 4 being the boring exception here) You also have the Extra type NPC's who just stand around saying their one liners just like later games.Another thing shared is the Lore and if nothing else people can may pick up some background info on the Fallout Lore and have a chance in some form to visit alot of the places and NPC's that are mentioned in later games. Many other things feel very different because its like comparing two different games an old isometric game vs a modern FPS RPG with a few hints and references that your in the same world. Overall Fallout 1 Is a good game but it has to be taken from a different approach to the later games.  Personally I would love to see Fallout 1 & 2 in the New vegas engine but most likely won't ever happen sadly.

												Being a fan of Fallout since Fallout 3, I've played New Vegas and Fallout 4 and loved them. But I wanted more. When I first played this, I got to Vault 15 and it told me that I had to look somewhere else to find the chip. I was like no way and put the game down for a few months. About a week ago I decided to pick it back up again and I started a new game and played it from start to finish, getting my good ending, completing a whole ton of shi* and quests. This game is fantastic, a classic. Quite the roleplaying game. A good change of pace from the newer fallouts, and it makes me happy. Seriously, give this game a try and play it until you get the hang of it, and don't just put it down because you don't understand it. Play it until you get the water back to the vault and then you aren't as pressured as badly with time and can do whatever the hell you want in the world.-Love Dakota

r 18, 2016
												Owning this game as a big box PC game, I thought i'd buy the game on Steam to see if it still holds up today.Spoiler: It Does.Fallout is a very challenging game, especially if you compare it with later installments of the franchise such as Fallout 3 and 4. Don't let the isometric graphics fool you, this game is no cake-walk.From the beginning to end of the game, I was mindblown by the immense detail implemented into the world of Fallout 1, something 3 and 4 wished they could've acheived, 4 more so. Using past experience with the game, I was able to beat the game in around 10 hours, but if you are new to this game, expect this number to increase massively for you. If you are new and playing without a guide, you have balls of steel. People in the Classic Fallout community have acheived crazy things within Fallout 1 such as getting power armor at level 1, and other such things.Overall, Fallout, from 1997, achieves a more immersive role-playing experience than it's 3D counterparts, with the exception of New Vegas, of course.Also, I recommend getting a mod called "Fallout Fixt". It basically irons out all of the creases the original release had, such as bugs, and the time limit to find the damn water chip , which was always a pain in the ♥♥♥.10/10 - Amazing, immersive experience.

												After replaying this game after about 4-5 years, I have to say it is one of the greatest RPGs ever made. The Fallout universe is so rich and enticing. As you progress through the world of Fallout the way you go about your quests truly effects the world. This also effects the end game, as it shows you how you've effected the world and there is many varying endings.Overall this is a fantastic game, if you love Fallout, RPGs, tactical RPGs, stratergy games (To some extent) and games that are story driven, Fallout has it all! 10/10

content:
r 30, 2014
												It is a somewhat pointless attempt for me to write a review of the first installment of the Fallout series, because I LOVE IT SO MUCH. I have to admit, that I'm a sort of a fanboy of this game (and for some extent of its sequel Fallout 2). This might be my all time favourite video game. I absolutely fell in love with it back in 1997.I love the 50s inspired retrofuturistic post-apocalyptic RPG setting. I love the character and combat systems. The overall graphics and especially the brutal ultra-violent death animations still please me. I absolutely love Mark Morgan's ambient soundtrack that reminds me of Aphex Twin's album "Selected Ambient Works Volume II". The player can approach quests multiple ways depending on the character stats. The consequences of player's actions affect the whole Wasteland. The choices really feel like they matter. This truly feels like playing a RPG.I admit there are some major technical limitations and some frustrating stuff throughout the game (Thanks Ian, for blasting me into a bloody mess with the SMG once AGAIN!), but the Fallout's awesomeness tops all that.If you enjoy this, you'll probably also like Fallout 2 even though I find it inferior to its predecessor for screwing up the setting at some parts. (I can't recommend the other sequels and spinoffs, because I haven't played them.)But yeah, I really recommend this! I LOVE LOVE LOVE IT!

r 28, 2016
												I am someone who started the Fallout series with Fallout 3 when it came out, I then proceded to buy Fallout New Vegas, and Fallout 4 and I love the series, but after beating 4 a couple times I still wanted more so I decided to pick of the Fallout classic collection. I beat Fallout 1 and man was it good, for many reasons.The story starts out with a simple plot but then starts to get exciting later wich I won't spoil, and has some of the most interesting character, some of whom make an apperiance in future tittles, and the one of the best villians in any game to this day. The world was a blast to explore, with interesting places to explore, although not huge like current Fallout games. The character creation was great, and as much as I liked Fallout 4 the leveling system was dumbed down from its predisessors and quite awful, but Fallout 1 has a great leveling system with skills, attributes, perks wich any rpg gamer will love. Also the replay value is high with the ability to join raiders and kill everybody, to the choice to speak your way out of everthing and kill nobody, this game is solid and still lives up to this day. I highly recommend you go purchase this NOW!

content:
y 20, 2016
												Note: Do not attempt to play this if you have played Fallout 3, 4, and New Vegas first! Do some research before buying Fallout 1.Where do i begin? You know it is amazing to see how far the Fallout series has gotten. And to think it started out like this. Most Fallout gamers will come to believe it's like the ones you see now.....it isn't. Not even close. Sure it has everything that makes Fallout very well known. But it plays extremely different. The game is two things. Turn based, and RPG. Turn base only happens during combat sequences and the RPG mechanics are completely everywhere. From the "Character creation" when you first start it. To the dialouge and choices you make throughout Fallout 1.This game is filled with content and lore that will make your head spin....or to make you rage quit at certain moments. It is best to save often because you will be needing it.....a lot. The skills and SPECIAL sort of works like what you see now. But it handles it a bit differently. My advice, is to do some research on the skills in Fallout 1 and how they work, same goes with SPECIAL. The only negative thing i could say about Fallout 1. Is mainly the Action Point system it's your everything during combat sequences from going into your inventory to choosing between vats mode and what i call "shootout mode" (Regular combat).I could've mentioned the story but it's best if you do the research first before buying like i noted in the "note" section above. Other than that if you want a blast from the past this game is for you.

content:
ry 2, 2016
												This is downright my favorite RPG ever made, but you gotta keep in mind, this game came out in 1997 and all I was doing at that point was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my diapers, I have no nostalgic sentiment for this game and it was in no way colored by idealized childhood memories. When I was younger, my favorite RPGs were KotOR and its sequel, and I sank like 1000 hours in both I'm sure. So I do have nostalgia out the ♥♥♥ for those games and I do have idealized memories. I played FO1 for the first time in the 2010s, and the experience is so good it stands up to and even towers over the RPGs I loved as a kid. Nostalgia is a powerful force and if you can beat that, that's a really good sign.The port job here is actually one of the few times I can say the Steam version of an old game is a completely tolerable  version, as Bethesda has come in and spruced up the game with some updates, most importantly adding the ability to use widescreen resolutions. The game runs pretty much fine, and the only real issue I can remember is it may rarely crash, and if you alt tab, the screen will be black but it has this weird thing where you uncover the screen by moving the mouse? I fonud that bringing up the pip boy or skills menu was a quick way to fix that.And the game is excellent, the theming is incredible, the art design is old but holds up amazingly well to the point that the gore in this game will still make you go "OH ♥♥♥♥ THO". It's an amazingly tight experience, the quests are fun and memorable, the characters are fun and memorable with many of them depicted with these talking heads made out of clay or some ♥♥♥♥ that look cartoony but still look cool to this day. And the music is some masterpiece level ♥♥♥♥, with this and it's sequel boasting some of the best soundtracks in games ever, and this is before they had the disk space to just borrow 20 songs from the 30s-60s so it features mostly original compositions.I won't spoil anything but I will tell yout hat the lead villain is immediately one of the best in gaming history if not *the* best, the kind that can stand shoulder to shoulder with Andrew Ryan or KotOR 2's easily, but I can't go in to even basic details because spoilers.The game does feature an in-game timer, however this is not something you should be anxious about because your natural pace will probably be more than enough to get you to complete said timer in time, and once you do that you have all the time in the world to explore the world. The only limit from then on is 13 years, but that's a vast amount more than anyone would ever play because even the most slow player would see all the content in the game before that's even close to being over.The controls may be intimidating at first with the classic CRPG interface that we've been distanced from, but trust me, it's not all that hard to learn and most character builds can get through the game fine, Hit, I believe F1, and you can bring up a screen that shows you what everything is and does.I gotta say, from the bottom of my heart, Fallout 1 is an absolute classic gem even by modern day standards. If you're a modern day Fallout fan, a fan of CRPGs, or just a fan of RPGs, you owe it to yourself to give this a shot. Seriously, get it.

												The very first game of the series that spawned a great franchise. In Fallout, you play as a vault dweller who must save his vault from dying by getting a new water chip. However, you find out that there's more to saving the vault than just a water chip. The game is an isometric turn-based RPG and requires you to use various skills to progress through the game, such as picking locks on doors, bartering with NPC's and taking out various enemies with a wide array of arsenals. This game is nearly perfect, would recommend to anyone that wants to play an older, more challenging RPG games.

content:
er 13, 2015
												Fallout is probably one of the most immersive RPG's I've ever played in my entire experience with gaming. For this review I'll divide it into categories of the game and discuss the "Pros and Cons". Gameplay Mechanics Fallout's gameplay is entirely dependant on the character that you create. This can vary based on the perks and skills you pick up as you progress through the game. The stats of this game are "what make you  S.P.E.C.I.A.L ". Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Luck. Strength affects your overall carry weight and melee damage. Perception allows you to have more dialogue options, higher ranged accuracy and the distance in which you encounter random hostilities. Endurance modifies your health, resistance to poison/radiation, healing rate and hit points recieved upon leveling up. Charisma is what affects player interaction between NPC's. This stat will give the player the ability to barter more efficiantly and open up dialogue options. Intelligence allows the player to recieve more skill points upon leveling up, more dialogue options and skills. One thing I should also mention is that characters with very low intelligence are very funny to play as. I reccomend doing so if you want a good laugh. Agility allows the player to have more action points in combat and move faster in game. Lastly, Luck grants players bonuses to accuracy, critical damage chance and the gambling skill of the player. Perks also affect your character to further shape what you ideally want. For example, the perk "Small Frame" will give your character enhanced speed and more action points at the cost of strength.Combat in Fallout 1 is turn based. The amount of moves a player has is dependant on action points. Swift characters may have more action points, but could deal little to no damage if that is the only invested skill. Slow, but heavy characters can dish out loads of damage and possibly tank enemies to give companions opportunities of attacking, but can rarely move due to an undeveloped Agility skill. Combat is entirely dependant on what you want (like stated earlier). The various ways it can be shapen into is what gives this game replayability.Various skills such as Barter, Sneak, Lockpick, Doctor, First Aid are the factors that also affect combat. For example, if the player creates a merchant character (someone with high Charisma and Barter) then that player can profit off of NPC's and have access to numerous buffs and expensive items. Characters with high Sneak and Big Guns make great Snipers that pick off enemies and assist companions. Story You play as the Vault Dweller of Vault 13. The Overseer calls you as he needs your assistance in saving the vault. The water purification chip that provides drinking water to the Vault inhabitants is broken. He asks if you can adventure deep into the wasteland to bring back a waterchip and save the Vault. The player is only given 150 days to do so. This is the only information I feel is necessary to give as Fallout 1's story should really be experienced hands on. The only thing I will also mention is that the story will evolve into something more elaborate as you progress. Please, experience it for yourself. It becomes very philosophical. Immersive Factors: Music, Atmosphere, etc. Fallout 1 has an amazing soundtrack. It sets the tone of a dark, morbid post apocalyptic world. It embodies the wasteland that Western America has become. The hatred, emptiness and agony of the people that survived the nuclear destruction is captivated in this soundtrack. Like I said before, experience this for yourself. All I can do is praise it.The setting of this game takes place in the west coast of America. Due to the Great War sand and radiation is all that's left in the world. Throughout the game, you will discover settlements, villages, caves and cults. They're well made artistically and the music compliments them well.The people of Fallout will vary morally. The characters of this game juxtapose nicely as many of them have different interests. You have people seeking to bring justice and law to the wasteland, greedy and power hungry individuals that only care about their self benefit and an elitest group that I do not want to spoil. Overall Rating If you're a fan of RPG's then purchase this game immediately. I can say with utmost certainty that you will enjoy this game. You will be kept immersed and entertained. Let this game also prove that modern graphics aren't what make a game. This was released in 1997 and to this day it still has an incredibly large following.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
8, 2016
												"War... War Never Changes..."War may never change, but this game changed me back in early 1998 when I herd about a game where you could make choices that impact the world around you and do anything you wanted, even shoot up a friendly town.  In the golden age of C-RPGs, Interplay (lead br Brian Fargo, now of InXile) made some of the best RPGs ever to grace any gaming platform and this was one of them.  The Fallout series was progressive for many reason including its gameplay and player choices that impacted the game.  One interesting and frequently overlooked one is that Fallout 2 was the first game where you could marry a person of the same gender... but, lets get back to the game.Closely mirroring many aspects of its spiritual predecessor, Wasteland, Fallout is set in a desolate post nuclear apocalyptic environmental.  Fallout's dark adult humor, S.P.E.C.I.A.L. stat system, striking setting, strong narrative, characters and RPG elements are among far to numerous reasons to mention why Fallout was a not just a great and immersive RPG, but an amazing experience for any gamer playing it at the time... and it's still a trip now if you don't mind the dated graphics.  Although, it won't be quite as shocking as it was at the time and it doesn't have as much to do as a modern open world RPG, it's important to keep in mind this was released in 1997.Maybe it's a bit nostalgic to say, but Fallout isn't just a amazing game, it's a piece of gaming history for influencing all the other games in the genre that followed it and all of the people who played it.You can beat the game without ever firing a single shot or dropping a single body... but I highly recommend selecting "Bloody Mess" and taking your weapon of choice and creating as much pixelated carnage as possible because, well, the wasteland won't show you any mercy and you might as well have some fun before Ian inevitably shoots you in the back with an SMG on burst and leaves you to enjoy a premature "Game Over" screen... **SPOILERS**Truly 10/10... Would get addicted to nuka cola, not return Tandi to her home and instead keep her with me, never give Ian a knife and shoot him myself first with a modified plasma rifle before he can "accidently" kill me, beat a super computer at chess, have brain surgery to raise my intelligence and surgeory to make me sexier, steal parts to build power armor from an organization trying to rebuild humanity's technology, have a K9 companion follow me through the wastes, and have a critical failure that unloads my weapon when fighting the final battle at the worst possible time again... and again... and again... and again...P.S.  If you beat the game with "Bloody Mess" you treated to an extended (but brief) and totally fitting ending.  Also, look into getting some great mods.  Enjoy!

												I actually had fun playing this. There was lots of settlements and other places to explore. The story is great, the soundtrack is phenominal for its time. But as you know, every game has a negative aspect to it. One of them is that combat and getting from point a to be is extremely tedious and it's a little tough being patient with it. Probably the reason why I don't like it is because I've played Fallout 3 and New Vegas before this game so it's tough getting used to. The second thing is that you don't have the choice to walk away from a fight and the game just forces you to fight even though you don't really want to. But these issues are minor. Another thing that really catches my attention are the hilarious face models. There is a really funny easter egg in the game that when you click on credits in the menu and type "boom". It will show the creator of the games head being exploded. Anyhow, I give this game a B. Although this game is a little too similar to Wasteland (A game that the creator worked on as well) I would reccomend playing Fallout 2 more.

content:
2, 2015
However controversial it can be at times, it’s more than apparent that Fallout is a game that was made with a lot of love and I can tell you that more than fifteen years on it still shows.Here is one of the most fondly loved titles that developer Black Isle ever put out (the other being Planescape Torment), Fallout is a role playing game set in a post apocalyptic United States seeped in Fifties retro futurism and Cold War Americana.With its rather drab palette of colours, eerie ambient music and simplistic combat, you’d think Fallout to be a false prophet at first glance but that’s before you’ve experienced the writing. Every NPC you chat with and almost every action you take in-game is accompanied by strings of incredibly well written text that develop the game’s setting much further than its meager appearance would might usually allow.This is a one-of-a-kind series that redefines what a mature and well written RPG really is.Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]
