Try this game as soon as possible - you won't be disappointed.

content:
ry 8
												Fallout 1This game is a classic cRPG for a reason, And very good one, The game holds up extremely well even today.Fallout 1 makes you a vault dweller, Someone who has to save his/ her Vault. The game starts you out very humbly, A lowly weak character fighting rats to get out of the cave that holds you're Vault, But soon you'll find a town, Some friends, And some weapons. Once you begin to figure out the game, You start to get your hands on more information, and more weapons, This game does a great job at pacing this. One of the biggest reasons you'll end up enjoying the game is because of how rich the world is, Every faction has purpose. You don't feel like the only important character, Infact most places would survive with or without you. It helps a lot in making you feel like a character in a world, Instead of the hero of the wastes that is the only one who can solve problems. The combat in the game is probably the weakest aspect of the game but for what it is, It works fine. The has some fun moments with the luck element. Characters use AP during each turn, To ethier move, shoot, reload, or go into inventory, and at the end of each turn, Your AP refreshes. The system itself is fine, except the maximum combat speed for the game isn't as fast as you'd like when you have 12 people or more in a fight. Usually the game keeps fights to numbers under 10 except for special moments which are fun, just hope you don't have to reload. Also the AI can be frustating to say the least at times. Getting hurt and running away into more trouble, or just being in the way, But for the most part they do their jobs and they do them fine.The Dialogue system will also give you a lot to work with, And A lot to enjoy. The dialogue system in this game is one of the best and most interesting parts of this game, You couldn't get so invovled in the world if you couldn't learn anything about it. Thankfully you have a ton of characters to talk to, learn from,  joke with, or insult in all manner of ways, Just be smart enough. The game's dialogue system is incredibly deep. You can't just say the "right" thing to a character, You need to think about their character and argue to what they would want to hear, Telling a evil man he's evil won't do much, But asking him to stop for something might. It makes you feel think, And makes you feel more invovled in the wasteland.Overall Fallout 1 still holds up as one of the best RPGs you can get on a PC, If you are a fan of oldschool games, Fallout, Table top RPGs, or just classic great games, You should have Fallout 1 and 2. This game is worth every cent you could possibly throw at it.

Players today aren't used to the old control schemes of the old days, so a little bit of fiddling around in how to properly control stuff is suggested, as well as reading the manual that comes with the game. My Personal Score: 3/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]Issues: none experienced during playthroughs.Fallout is one of those classic games that never ceases to charm me everytime I play it. Being the root title in the behemoth of a franchise that it has become, there's nothing quite like exploring a post-apocalyptic Southern California in an isometric view and role-playing with Interplay's primordial SPECIAL system which still offers a unique gameplay experience despite its age. It's going to be jarring to play this game coming from the 3D sequels what with the lack of explanations for the mechanics and skill checks at every turn ala pen and paper RPGs but if you take the time to learn all of its intricacies and having the mindset to play a game like this, you'll be rewarded with a one-of-a-kind experience that only old school RPGs could offer.And there you have it.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
"War, war never changes!"Said Ron Perlman back in 1997 when the first Fallout game was released by the company called Interplay. Unlike Fallout 3 this and its sequel put more emphasis on role-playing. Make no mistake - there's lots of fights but not that many weapons as introduced in later episodes, plus, there's no VATS system here making a single fight like a cutscene.A propos cutscenes: there are many such events occurring when we are met by new people - people that are important in the world and can bring the story forward. We complete quests, gather experience points, converse with strange people (even the zombie-like inhabitants of Necropolis), fight mutants and huge, red scorpions - all in a post-nuclear, radioactive, infested world that looks as if the '50s technology was brought forward. This retrofuturistic atmosphere certainly gives a plus to the gameplay.While there are 3 characters pre-made by the creators you can always create your own here with the game's SPECIAL system (acronym for Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Luck). Plus, you have perks, attributes, skills etc. This is a rather complex system that later iterations of the franchise all inherited.I know Fallout 4 looks better and uses all the current-gen graphical enhancements but if you want to know where it all started and you have around 30 hours for such a pastime (this is for completionists) then picking this one might just be an exciting story for you.PS: The number of hours I invested into the game can be measured in the dozens. This was the commercial version that was released way before Steam hence the short time spent with the game here. Still, it was nice to see that the Steam edition works well and offers even a full HD resolution.

content:
r 24, 2016
												This review does contain spoilers and such, so be wary.Fallout 1, even as it has nearly been around for nearly 19 years, is still easily one of the best Fallout games in the franchise. Games such as Fallout 3 are only a 10th, maybe even less, than what this game was, even New Vegas as much as I love it, didn't come close to the experience I got from this.The quest was simple. Find a water chip to save your vault from certain death. Only leaving you with one location of a second Vault (Vault 15). Except when you leave on your mission, you find yourself getting caught up in the problems of other villagers and learning of new unknown locations, how these locations have grown and prospered. Not because you asked for quests, but because the town was placed in the middle of you and your location, not because you were told to. This happens again, with the hub, as you enter not knowing what you'll find, only to get yourself tangled between a shop keeper and a large casino owner in their feuds for business and profit, without you having to ask. And you get to decide who comes out on top, either with one dying or the other, both having their own pros and cons and each side having their reasons for their actions. As you travel further, you learn of factions, areas and dilemmas that you are able to choose who reigns victorious, whether it's the blades or the regulators, shady sands and the raiders, the ghouls of underground necropolis and set, along with the mutants, all while building up information on the much higher, more powerful threat that awaits. The super mutants are in general, dumb and strong, but compared to their creator, they are merely pawns in the larger plan that awaits. You only meet the antagonist once, at the very end, but it feels as if you've known him for longer. He never taunts you or mocks you on your journey, nor is he mentioned beyond the whispers of the cathedral. But you've been learning about him since you began, and it's incredibly fascinating to learn what you missed if you ever go for a second playthrough, which I highly recommend, and is even more of a wonder if you continue to Fallout 2 and absorb the lore, which if you enjoyed then I cannot recommend it enough. His presence is enough to give you goosebumps and you'll remember certain lines from him for a long time. Words can only put it so far. The best way to find out, is to play it. Next to 2, this is an outstanding experience, and makes you forget all about graphics, animations and gives you the freedom to delve into the attention to detail, the characters and the story. If you've played New Vegas, then I highly recommend this, but if you've came from 3 then this game might come as a bigger surprise than you might expect.

content:
5, 2015
Brown. Brown Never Changes. - An Official Waffle King Review~Find more here.[lordwaffleking.com]Incredibly dark, gritty games are very bountiful these days. Almost everything is trying to be THAT game. You know the one. More shades of brown than the cast of a black sitcom. Everything's gotta be super dark and serious. This is war, man. There's gotta be lots of blood and explosions, and brown. This is serious. People die, man. Death is real. It's coming for you.It wasn't always this way though. It used to be different. It used to be a happier, more peaceful gaming landscape. Sure, there were serious games. There were games with blood, games with death, and games with brown.Super Mario wears brown shoes.But you kids that are always ♥♥♥♥♥ing about not having enough color in games and all games being too dark, you don't know. It used to be something special. It used to be a unique art direction. At least until everyone jumped on the bandwagon and completely ♥♥♥♥ all over it. There was an original brown game. A game that said, hey, you know the color brown? Well guess what, it's everywhere. And it was a pleasant surprise.The original is still by far one of the bests. It's got the unique art direction, the atmosphere, and it's charming in its own special way. In a sort of, giving a Get Well balloon to roadkill kind of way.Fallout is the original grit. Fallout is the original brown. Brown before brown. Rocks and sand before rocks and sand. The first Fallout. Way back in 1997. Surprise, the Fallout series did not start on 3. There was a first game.Fallout is a truly spectacular game. A marvel of classic RPG's, and arguably better than some modern RPG's in what it offers. Fallout is an open-world, turn-based tactical RPG. Set in an alternate future where Donald Trump became president and everything went to hell, you must set off from the safety of your underground vault to repair the satellite so grandma can watch Spongebob again. She gets cranky if she can't watch Spongebob.There's a pretty large emphasis on you as the character. There are a few pre-made characters to choose from in case you don't know how to choose your stats properly, but it's best if you make your own. Using the "S.P.E.C.I.A.L." system, which stands for "Strength, Perception, Endurance, Charisma, Intelligence, Agility and Lemons" you can make your characters as unique as you like. Assign them special skills and traits, and make them special.Not only do you have complete freedom in creating your character, but the game alters dramatically in how you play it based on your character and your choices. It's like some kind of Mass Effect kinda ♥♥♥♥, but like, before Mass Effect. Can you believe that? They had good game ideas this long ago? That's amazing.The major choices and karma system aren't the only familiar elements. There's also a time limit. If you don't get your vault up and running properly again, everyone dies and you're left to feel the shame of disappointing everyone in your life. Also they're all dead.A tricky gameplay element. On one hand, it limits exploration of Fallout's vast world. But on the other hand, it gives you a sense of urgency in your mission. It helps to drive home that feeling of desperation, of helplessness in a desolate world. It also keeps your playthrough fairly contained and quick. There's more to the game, much more. But with so many choices and options, limiting yourself to one long playthrough instead of a lot of smaller ones limits how much of the game you're actually seeing.Fallout has so much depth, and such a dynamic world. In my time with it, I experienced multiple different and unique playthroughs.In my first playthrough, my great hero Dubya set off into the wasteland to save the world. Dubya was a strong guy, but not a smart one. Or one that survived all that long. He spent days crawling through the very first cave, killing every rat he could. Unfortunately, I chose for him to have extra strength at the cost of his accuracy, so the poor guy was trying to punch rats for almost a week. And getting bit, and dying. He finally made it out into the wasteland, where he tried to punch scorpions until he died.At this point, I realized that Dubya wasn't working out and made a new character. Nookyalur, the agile Vault person, used her cunning wit and agility to steal some weapons, which she used to kill everything she could. She made it further, and eventually went on to die in a killing spree when she got in a fight with a merchant and his guards. She had to be left behind when she ran out of time, and her vault crumbled without its precious Spongebob reruns. Not the new ones, those are ♥♥♥♥. It's gotta be the old episodes.It was at this time that I managed to get a grip on how the game worked. So I simply restarted once more, and didn't ♥♥♥♥ up my character. With my powerful stealth and science abilities, I was able to sneak into a military base and set it to self-destruct. So in one fell swoop, without even equipping my gun, I killed so many things. So many. I got like a million experience points.From there, I managed to break my way into another base, and steal some power armor. I was pretty much invincible at this point, probably. So I saved the world, discovered the mutated remains of Donald Trump's hairpiece, and foiled his plan to end immigration once and for all.It was a pretty dank ride.Though all along my journey were other options. Did I recruit the guy with the gun into my party to help me kill things? Or did I go it alone, and use stealth to my advantage? Did I use my awesome talking powers to convince the bad guys to not kill me? Or did I slaughter them all without even blinking? Or do I agree with Donald Trump's immigration policies and decide to vote for him? I can't choose every choice in one playthrough.Even though I've played through the game a number of times, there's still so much I've yet to see. There are different endings, different choices. There are areas I've yet to fully explore, even. It's that deep and complex of a game.On the other hand, Fallout is pretty old. It's not as pretty as one of the modern Fallout games. It's not as user-friendly with its interface either. The interface is clunky by our standards today, but still definitely usable. It also has that "old RPG" vibe of all but requiring you to talk to everyone and everything. There aren't any glowing trails to show where you're going, or any markers to show what to do. You may even need a guide to help you through some areas.That's the only real issue that could turn someone away from Fallout. It's kinda old. And kinda dated in a few ways. At its core, it's still one of the great CRPG classics. C standing for cougar. It's that old, but it's still got it. And probably the mother of something, being that old and influential. So you could say Fallout is a milf, I guess.Milfs aren't for everyone. Some like them incredibly modern and fresh. But personally, I always had a thing for retro. Know what I'm saying?If you can look past Fallout's clunky old interface and admire it for its genius game design and aged beauty, Fallout will be good to you. If not, hey, I bought my copy for like a dollar. Besides, now I can brag about how cultured and refined I am for owning retro classics like Fallout. Like owning bottles of wine you'll never drink. You never know when you'll need to impress your guests with how refined you are. Even if you'll spend the rest of the night throwing up and sobbing.I feel as though Fallout has taught me valuable lessons though. Lessons about life, and the world. Like, if there ever was a nuclear apocalypse? We'd pretty much all be dead. Isn't that a comforting thought? We'd all be so very screwed, but at least we'd be dead. And that's okay with me.

content:
5, 2015
												Fallout 1 is an old game. It held up decently though. You get sent out form your little hole in the ground community to get a new water chip. Because it's a wasteland full of hardened criminals and raiders - and you're the one that's less likely to get killed if you go into the world with merely a rusty knife (seriously a gun would have made more sense but I guess gaming rules have to go the route of "Start with nothing and work your way up").As this game's lore goes somewhere in the 1950s the apocolypse happened. The details are pretty unimportant as the war is something that's from a time no one cares about anymore. It was at least a generation or two ago. But the results of it lasted: a wasteland covering the entire world as far as most around can tell.One of the first things I discovered in this was it's very eager and able to kick your ♥♥♥. Sometimes simply walking into a public area is enough for the whole place to kil you. if you die you die perminently. if your party members die they die perminently. There's no revive in any sense of the word for this game. And it takes almost no time at all before any ally you get dies if you aren't abusing saves to redo every fight they died in. It wasn't until I managed to get ahold of Power Armor when I started feeling somewhat badass.It's possible that I am to blame though what with having prioritized non combat skills such as bartering and speach. I garuntee you'll never have any money issues if you put heavy amounts into bartering and charisma. When you start reaching 90% shops start paying you more than you pay them. So you can actually keep trading the same items between each other and just have them pay some caps on top of that - effectively walking away with the entire store for free if you wanted to.The AI in Fallout 1 is pretty terrible. If it's not simply blocking your way so you can't walk through a door for 2-3 minutes straight (and oh does it ever do that a lot) it's jumping in front of you in combat or worse burst firing so it'll kill everyone in front of it - often other party members and yourself. 40% of this game's difficulty comes from the party you babysit. The party doesn't level up with you so they quickly become flat out obsolete. With little to no personality or story surrounding them you really won't feel bad just giving up and letting them die when they die. They're practically faceless. I did find it pretty cool you could have multiple followers though. It actually felt like a party of travelers... until it became babysitting anyway. they lose their appeal when a single super mutant kills all of them with a single attack in your general direction.The turn based top-down combat was not what I expected when I started playing. It was honestly pretty good once the followers weren't involved though.This game suffered from lacking in explaination for the interface. There were some things that were vital to know - such as how to set traps or disable them, how to use stimpacks or how to use items on the environment (which left me stuck near the end of the game as I didn't know how to hook up a radio to a computer until I looked up help online).It also suffered from some nonsense errors throughout the game - such as trying to operate a switch to open a door and getting a "no space in inventory" response.Also deathclaws are hell. I have to point them out because ♥♥♥♥ deathclaws. The only way they could be harder is if when you killed them a second one popped out of the carcass of the first - wearing power armor and holding a minigun. And instead of bullets it shot more deathclaws out from it.It's a good game. By today's standards I'd give it a 6/10 realistically, but a 7/10 for fan-factor.

												Perhaps the strongest aspect of Fallout is that it is ideal for RPG newbies yet at the same time provides a depth of role-playing that veterans can really get stuck into. It also has the best replay value of any game I've experienced to date.The game play is smooth, using action points for movement and combat and the inventory system is easily managed. Fallout has one of the best character development systems of any computerized role-playing game and the graphics and story make for an excellent gaming experience.For anyone with an interest in complex, combat-heavy, lovingly produced RPGs Fallout is a must buy. In an age where many are predicting the death of traditional RPGs at the hands of multiplayer extravaganzas, Fallout is a glowing example of the genre, one which positively radiates quality. Fallout – it's da bomb.

Then get suspicuos and repeat the process by reloading a save until you get into that room, equip hardened power armour, kill super mutants and find out the computer they were protecting sets a timer for a nuke to blow in 4 minutes.Overall Great game, if you haven't got it then go and get it

content:
5, 2015
												Fallout has got to be a hidden gem under my radar. Is still a good classic game and still held up after all those years. You feel like you have to work up your loot, weapons and armor to survive, like in a real fallout scenario especially when you have to talk "smart" to some people and make deals to get on thier good side if you want to progress the game further, and man the beginning is brutel (depends on settings) for me if you don't know what you're doing! The only 3 problems I can think of that bothers me is the trading system has a problem and is you can only trade stuff one digit at a time. Is annoying if you have alot of caps. so you have to click it so many times until you reach your number of caps to trade, is ridiculous for how simple it is to fix it. The second is a nitpick and is from the beginning that you have to figure it out on your own how the controls work and which button does it do. Some that are vital like the iconic focus aim shots, I later found the feature in mid game, which I could have learn it sooner before I die alot from the mutants.The third is the fighting system where depends on how many action points you have, you attack on the person, but if the person say 3 guys attack you and you only get one or two actions to attack, the others guys get 8 combine! Even if you're fighting one guy he gets probably 3 or if you're lucky 2 actions. And yes you can increase it, but is so slow to get more action points if you don't know what you're doing. You have to plan your attacks carefully and not strike it blindly which is good, but is hard if you need the exp. Yes, you can decrease the difficulty and plan making a better character but is just my take on my first playthrough.There has been some crashes on my Win. 7 34 bit but only when I input certain commands or moves of the game for reason I don't know why so watch out if it happens. I don't know if it'll work on 64 bit or win 8 but I know they have patches for that on some website that I don't know if it'll work, look it up in youtube.I give an 8/10 rated for a classic gem series that still holds up to a fun level.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2014
												if you dont like older games or slow gameplay than i would advise not buying this game, however for being as old as it is, this title as aged quite well. even the graphics for the combat,areas,and characters are muddy at best, the overall story and feel of adventure you get when traverising the wastes is enough to keep you wrapped up for several hours of gameplay. one of the major flaws however is that it is quite buggy, for instince, i once had a broken arm so i was unable to fire two handed weapons but the game wouldnt let my character or any of the in game doctors fix it.                                                                 As i stated before the combat is slow but very involving and strategical, if youve ever played any x-com games than you will understand the mechanics exaclty. this allows the game to make situations more tense and difficult forcing to do more than just charging in and blasting dudes in the face, but is not such a bad thing. when you have to slow down and analyze scenarios, the combat is more involving and satisfying, because unlike other games where you can just shoot this random dude in the face, you can hide and set up explosives to blow his legs off, run up, and then shoot him.                            one major drawback to the gameplay though is the fact that there is a time limit of 400-500 in game days before you lose the game, so its something like dead rising 2's sand box, where you can goo off and have fun just dont expect a happy ending. also the display screen for your weapons and perks could be a bit more descriptive, but considering the pace games where at that time were at i'll let that one pass.                the last thing i wamt to talk about is the plot whic is actually pretty original considering the setting being completely cliche( post-apcolyptic america). you are a resident of one of the many vaults that protected a select few but one day the water chip begins to go down and you are chosen to brave the wastes and retrieve another. in your adventures you come across such things as crashed aliens, dr. who, deathclaws, giant master race mutats, raiders, and shotgun wileding robo-brains. you must battle all of these and more as you search for your vault's salvation. like i said pretty original.           So all in all it may be old and have some minor faults its still a pretty solid, and one of the best rpgs of all time. if you like turnbased combat, awesome storytelling,and hours of fun then this game is for you. i would rate it 9/10.

content:
ber 1, 2016
												Learns I need to acquire water purification chip to save my Vault, leaves Vault and proceeds to other Vault assuming I will find chip there. Stumbles across Shady Sands and learns they have a radscorpion problem, continues my journey to the vault only to learn that I need to descend an elevator shaft so I'll need a ladder or some rope. Goes back to Shady Sands and asks everyone I can about rope and ladders who all deny the existene of such things, Aradesh does not sell either. I learn of Junktown and a place called the Hub. So I travel to Junktown, they refuse me entry because it's night-time, I travel to the Hub and find a general store that sells rope at exorbitant prices. I purchase one rope, I go back to Vault 15. I descend the shaft, learn I need another rope. Return to the hub, purchase more rope, go back to the Vault. Discover there is no water purification chip there and find rope in a locker.From this day forward I always carry rope on my person 10/10 (The game is actually still really good, if you like today's Fallout games then you'll probably enjoy it.)

r 15, 2016
——— 8/10 ———+ Aesthetics
+ Immersion
+ Lore/Narration
+ Humor
+ RPG System

+/- Replayability
+/- Score

- Tutorial
- Gameplay Diversity
- RNG-dependant balance
- Internal Economic
Despite any hype about F1, unfortunately in terms of complexity it is more like oversized Fallout 2 demo, than real RPG itself, basically 90% of possible content could be seen through single "munchkin" playthrough, but most of game-builds is either combat unplayable or meaningless in terms of quest usage. By modern criterias many key systems out-dated, especially in case of UI. Text content is worth look into it, but I can't say that playing first Fallout was particulary joyfull expirience. It is rise of legend, true canon, but not best possible game.

												Here's a recap of my first half-hour on one of my playthroughs.I created a character and named him Beowulf, and I poured all my points into maxing out his Strength and Agility.I then decided to NOT equip the Brass Knuckles, in favor of beating the hell out of everything with my bare hands - in true Beowulf fashion.I then proceded to use this method to kill every rat in the cave, then went to Vault 15 and killed everything there.After that, I went back to Shady Sands, went to the RadScorpion Cave, and punched a RadScorpion so hard in the brain that I knocked it senseless, pacified it, and ended the combat with it still alive.I then walked over to it and ripped its tail off, still breathing.I have since then added a dog and a couple gun-toting thugs to my posse, and have saved a girl from a gang of Raiders by fighting their leader in bare-handed combat (won with hardly a scratch), then went and killed all of his subordinates for kicks.GOD DAMN, it feels good to be Beowulf.

content:
11, 2012
												Fallout is a fantastic game back in the day, but it is becoming pretty obvious that it did not age very well, to put it simply the gameplay and design is outdated. If you never had a knack to play ancient pc role-playing games, chances are pretty good you will not like Fallout. The control scheme is god awful compared to modern standards, and the repetitive textures are just visually boring. The gameplay is very standard for rpg game of the 90s. While Fallout may lack all the basic mechanics that makes modern games great, its storyline, environment, and sound will remain eternal. Fallout created a precedent for all great RPG’s to follow, the ability to shape the ending of the game started here. Much like its sequels, Fallout’s entire game world is flipping massive. Overall this game is in desperate need of a remake.

content:
20, 2013
												I played enough already to tell you that this game is a masterpiece and probably every oldschool gamers will tell you the same thing.Being a dystopia of the 50's in a post-nuclear war environment flooded with radiations, mutants and survivors. Fallout is much more open in its variety of choices and possibilities than, for example, Diablo 1 which came a year before.-You can Talk to almost every NPCs with multiple dialogue choices which will grant or deny you some ways to deal with problems.-Not a talker? Kill anyone in sight if you want! Pew pew pew! Takatakatak!A large variety of weapons can be found in the wasteland.-To be (A thief) or not to be? Pick any pocket in sight to get ammo, money, etc!-7 SPECIAL abilities such as : Strengh, Intelligence, Charisma, Luck...-18 skills such as : Small/Big Guns, Lockpick, Steal, Science, Speech...-53 perks such as : Animal Friend, Flower Child, Explorer, Fortune Finder...-Choose 2 personal traits between 16 choices such as :Bloody Mess, Good Natured, Jinxed, Skilled, Kamikaze...-You can take drugs and booze to boost your SPECIAL and Skills(WARNING : May cause addiction)-You can roam the wasteland freely without any limitations but the map borders.-The gunplay and combats are turned based. I think it's perfect because it's probably the only gameplay possible to deal with the way guns works in it.A real-time f**k-fest of bullets would be insane and unplayable.The wanted realism gives a survival side and your health is a part of it.It's not like in Diablo where you can boost your life, use magic and surealist stuff.After playing more or less 1000h hours on Fallout 3, I can finaly say that Bethesda did a great job to reenact the awesomeness of the Fallout series.May the power of atom be with you wastelanders!

content:
er 11, 2015
												Interplay at it's finest.Created by Interplay's RPG divison (later known as Black Isle Studios for all their later Fallout games), Fallout is a ginormous Post Nuclear Role-Playing Game set in the aftermath of "the great war", where humanity got so ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ they just bombed everyone because they ran out of natural resources.You play a hapless ♥♥♥♥ living in Vault 13. Your vault's water purification system has been damaged. It's up to you and ONLY you to wander the wasteland of California to search for a new one. Released in 1997, Fallout is one of the most intricate and highly detailed RPG's of the '90s. All of your skills all play important parts in the game, unlike beth♥♥♥♥♥das "Charisma 4: Mass Effect Dialogue Options". There are multiple endings depending on your actions and routes taken, and it's completely up to you what you do with your time.The original version of Fallout had a in-game time limit of 150 days to find the water chip. If you ran out, you'd get the bad ending by default. This limit was patched out in the early days.The Fallout series has remained one of the most inspiring and amazing RPG games to ever play.♥♥♥♥ Bethesda, this is the REAL masterpiece. Don't mind the "fallout 4" ♥♥♥♥♥♥s in the comments of this review. If you are a RPG fan, this game belongs in your library.

content:
er 24, 2016
												I played the Bethesda Fallout's and was curious to see the origins of the series. Fallout 1, in my opinion, offered a more immaginative and rpg like erxpereince cmpared to 3 and NV,-You have verbose paragraphs full of description (might be a turnoff to some)-Since characters aren't animated, you have to pay attention to their diologue to get important details about their character. -Diologue is also varied. Unlike Fallout 4, here you do have to consider what you're saying. You could accidently anger the other person, or start a fight, or acidentally get contracted to kll somebody even though you just wanted to find some work becasue apparently the wasteland is an expensive place to live in.........yeah-There is no pipboy telling you where to go, you hvae the overall goal of finding the water chip, but it's up to YOU to follow up on leads and tips. People tell you rumors or somethign they over heard and you follow up on that -the wasteland truly feels dangerous, here the stats mean more than anything. You can't just walk to the right and fight a super mutant, you'll get killed. The snese of progression is real, and the scarcity of items like stimpaks and radaway make finding them feel so much better.So, I'd recommend buying this if you want a more authentic rpg expereince in the fallout world. Note that you will be reading a lot of paragraphs since only 6 or 7 characters get their own animation and voice acting and you definetly will not know where to go your first time playing (though the game does offer a starting point so no worries). Don't be ashamed to look at a guide (this is a game from the 90s)

content:
ry 10, 2016
												A great Role Playing Game.  There are multiple ways to play this game.  You can be a bit of a diplomat, talking your way through the game.  You can use fire power to blast away most enemies.  Or you can look for a different approach, like finding an important computer and activating the self-destruct sequence of a place and leaving.  This is an older game, so don't expect great looking character models.Characters you find and add to your group can also be a pain in the butt at times.  They may fire at an enemy behind you, only to hit you instead.  Or they may block a door way and you have to wait for them to move.I did run into some gameplay issue with the more update version of the game, causing the game to crash.  I had to load up the older version to get around this.  Thankfully, this only happened in to areas of the game and did not ruin things (I was able to load up the updated version once I was past the area where the game would crash and would save there).This game can be difficult at times, as things may look favorable for you only to see your enemy get a BS lucky shot on you and kill you.  Overall, I really like this game, especially the ending.  After years of playing Japanese Role Playing Games, I got kinda tired of seeing everyone live happily ever after endings.  This game ending is harsh.  More fitting for the world of Fallout and the landscape, the Wasteland.  If you do plan to play this game, I do hope you do NOT look up the ending on YouTube.  It would possible ruin the experience for you and the work you character does in the game.

												Great game, especially for fans of the newer titles. If you're a fan of Fallout 3/NV or like old-school RPGs, play the first two Fallout games. Though the functionalities of an older game such as this do take a little bit of getting used to, once you get the hang of it it becomes a rich, very fun experience that is surprisingly similar to what you get in the newer titles. It's actually surprising to see just how much Bethesda got right when translating Fallout 3 into an updated 3D version of the same universe. And although there are some (not uncommon to modern Fallout) glitchy elements which definitely got smoothened out in the second installment, the original Fallout is a fun play even to this day, with an amazing story, hours of gameplay, funny moments, and some good 'ol turn-based combat that features some of the most gruesome and entertaining death scenes I've ever seen.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
29, 2015
How it All BeganThis is the original Fallout, complete with original graphics, blemishes and virtues. There is an incredible amount of depth to the world that you can inhabit. Time to go 'in depth' for my new review style. GameplayFallout 1 is an isometric RPG. It is, obviously, a little archaic. There are several different mouse pointers you must constantly alternate between to either examine, move or fight things. The combat is simple yet satisfying, with enough weapons and different combat approaches to each encounter that it can stay fresh. Moving through the desert is a harrowing, luck-based affair, with a grid-styled map that you can move through showing the world. Places of importance are highlighted in green, and random encounters stop you on your journey to keep it fresh. Overall, Fallout has impressive gameplay that stands up to the tests of time. StoryYour vault is running out of water. You are the last hope for your entire vault. This plot hook, though good, actually limits the game. A time limit is placed on you of 150 days, and if water is not obtained for your vault before the end of those 150 days, you will 'fail' the game. This places unnecessary pressure onto your shoulders, although it is incredibly effective at keeping players on the path of the main story. However, this leaves you with little opportunity to delve into other side missions or characters. Several characters will have to be made before you can experience everything. Graphics and AtmosphereQuite obviously the graphics are not going to be current-day good. Don't expect high quality graphics, and if you criticize the game for it's graphics... well then, what do you expect? It's the atmosphere that really sells the game. A broken landscape with intriguing characters and it's own, unique brand of humour really sells the unique vibe of a civilization that never got out of the 50's, and then got nuked. It's very enjoyable just to explore, even if there is no music. SummaryFallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a game that is very much worth your time. With a low asking price and hours worth of fun, there's very little reason that you shouldn't pick up the first Fallout, especially at a time like now when the future of Fallout is coming... why not return to the past?

content:
25, 2012
												One of the few games I recommend without hesitation.  Fallout 3 (a.k.a.: Oblivion 2) is total garbage, which completely lacks the mechanical equality, spirit, aesthetics and depth of its predecessors.  Fallout 3 is an open-world FPS that lacks the integral granularity to exist a an RPG, yet passes itself off as one as effectively as Steve Buscemi in drag.The REAL Fallout series represents an almost unparallelled RPG system in its complexity, balance and replayability.  Fallout is, without hyperbole, also one of the most influential games in history; it literally is the foundation for much of the modern PC (and PnP) RPG paradigm.Out of all the hundreds of RPGs I've played, Fallout 1&2 are still unquestionably in my top 5.

content:
er 25, 2016
												Newer generations typically won't appreciate the original Fallouts due to their dated graphics. There's something about Fallout 1 & 2 that Bethesda can't seem to replicate (although Obsidian did a great job with New Vegas). The grungy environment and original plot elements (instead of searching for your son/Dad) keep you constantly intrigued and/or amused with each twist and turn. Fallout 4 can't hold a candle to Fallout 1 or 2 because of one word. Replayability.The cult fanbase is well deserved, and even to this day there are total conversion mods being made for Fallout 2. Make sure to try out Fallout Resurrection and Fallout FIXT mods, or you'll be missing out.

content:

												One of the few games I recommend without hesitation.  Fallout 3 (a.k.a.: Oblivion 2) is total garbage, which completely lacks the mechanical equality, spirit, aesthetics and depth of its predecessors.  Fallout 3 is an open-world FPS that lacks the integral granularity to exist a an RPG, yet passes itself off as one as effectively as Steve Buscemi in drag.The REAL Fallout series represents an almost unparallelled RPG system in its complexity, balance and replayability.  Fallout is, without hyperbole, also one of the most influential games in history; it literally is the foundation for much of the modern PC (and PnP) RPG paradigm.Out of all the hundreds of RPGs I've played, Fallout 1&2 are still unquestionably in my top 5.

												Highly recommend, for any Fallout fan especially. But if you are not a big fan of Fallout, purchase with caution! This game has shown to be unpopular among people such as my friends. But if you're looking for a new post-apocolypse game, from a interesting old-timey prespective in the sky to play, I'd say give it a try!The game is amazing. A real great start to what would become the franchise of Fallout. There are many bugs like with any game, and in my opinion, this game is unfinished in vanilla version. With ending scripts and such not working, quests being non-avaible that break a players potentally desired choices, yadda yadda ... And I believe it was said because of time restraints. Which was sad, that they couldn't fix all this first.So because of these reasons, I point people toward looking up the mod "Fallout Fixt" which fixes basically all of this. A super mod that really re-added that kick in the game for me, after finishing it vanilla wise. Making it more so how it was expected to be played, and should be played. Though don't forget to play vanilla first alone, to see what I mean. Even adds a few other goodies too, which makes it all that sweeter. I consider this mod an essential part of the game when I play it now, you could say.Cough And between you and me, this may just be my favorite Fallout with the mod!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
r 3, 2016
												Tags : Isometric RPG - Post Apocalyptic*HALL OF FAME* *ALL-TIME FAVORITES*Heavily inspired by Pen and Paper. Gritty, well designed, solid dialogue, effective turn based combat. This can be a hard game, and you can seriously develop your character into a corner, or have a savegame that can no longer be salvaged and you will have to restart the game if you want to win the main mission. The requirements not to fail the main arc have been heavily relaxed through patching but I personally miss the classic difficulty of version 1.0. Game has been remastered somewhat to work on modern OS with modern resolutions and can be slightly modded by looking for files on the "no mutants allowed" forums. It can be necessary nowadays to modify the variable for random encounters in the desert as without them you do not level your combat oriented character nearly enough while travelling, and the amount of random encounters decreases as a function of CPU power, the higher the CPU the faster you travel the less encounters you face, it is strange but that is the way it is coded. This game among with others of its kind has gotten me hooked the isometric perspective and I personally love the work that went into the animations. The character models are reused heaviliy throuought the game however, but there is a fair amount of variety in tiles for locations so you do not always run into the same kind of maps. There is no procedural generation here everything was handcrafted.A masterpiece in my humble opinion and one that sets a personal standard for what a RPG is, your character and your choices will influence the play experience quite a lot here.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
ber 21, 2014
												It has taken me 15 years to complete Fallout 1. Some people say it's the best RPG of ALL TIME! I have found out the truth behind this claim.It's a third person isometric game from 1997. It ran fine on my widescreen Windows 7 set up. Note you need to running a patched version where some bugs are taken out. I played the Steam version that ran fine.The game is set in the USA in a post nuclear war era where much of civilisation has broken down or turned to dust. Some people have survived the nuclear fallout out by living in specialist underground bunkers called Vaults without much knowledge about the world above. You are tasked with saving your home after the water production breaks down.Before you jump ship and begin the quest to SAVE THE WORLD by killing some rats, you need to define your character. I found there was no right or wrong way to do this. Just that each choice will affect your adventure. Choosing a low Strength attribute won't allow you to lug around all the junk that you find. Agility effects action points in combat and how many gun shots you can attempt. Luck, usually a garbage stat effects your critical chances and also your random encounters. You also have skills and traits to choose and develop.You can't have a character that does everything well so you need to make choices on your play style. Go mighty sledgehammer or become a thief and pickpocket to riches. Specialise as a sniper or as a psycho killer, destroying everything that gives you a dirty look. Mwuahhaha!Saving your vault from water starvation is a small part of the overall story. It really gets interesting later on as you explore the desert and come across large towns and even a giant cathedral. Necropolis is full of zombie like ghouls and a super mutant group are on the rampage killing all before them. Then we have Deathclaws - legendary creatures that I found extremely vexing and impossible to take down. Eventually I figured out how shoot them in the leg or eyeballs.So, read the manual and figure out how to interact with the world. There is a learning curve and at the beginning you will feel lost. Damn - where are those pointers saying go there and do that. The end story was quite interesting and I really wish I could do a third play through - but on to Fallout 2.Oh - and don't ignore the timer to complete the initial water quest. I did on my first play through and the game promptly stopped when it said it would.Oh, I came across a TARDIS in the wastelands and then an alien ship that had crashed that contained a picture of Elvis. I also found an alien blaster that was awesome.Fantastic gem of a game. 8/10 as a modern game.

content:
8, 2015
												This game is legendarily great. The gameplay and story are compelling, but the world is the real star of the show here. That, and Harold and Dogmeat. They're stars too.Tips for companions:Dogmeat is a machine. Doesn't do much damage, but moves ridiculous distances, attacks 4 times a round, knocks enemies down all over the place so that you can 95% critical their eyes, and, most importantly, is the emotional heart of the story. I kept him alive all the way.Tycho is great. He's smart, durable, and funny. Just keep him stocked with shotgun shells and Stimpaks and he'll never let you down. Unfortunately, he died in the Cathedral.Ian is a staple for the first part of the game, but by the time you get power armor he's basically obsolete. I let him go eventually.Katja can mark the Cathedral on your map. That's about it. I made the mistake of giving her an SMG, and eventually abandoned her along with Ian. Hopefully they're fine in the middle of the desert.P.S. The gory death animations are fine, but the fact that they're used as rewards for winning makes them that much more priceless.P.P.S. I accidentally dropped Vree's holodisk moments after getting it in the Brotherhood base, later realized how important it is, went back, and, months later, it was still there. The Brotherhood really needs a janitor.

content:
ry 5, 2014
												10/10 - A shining pinnacle of human achievement.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GRAPHICS --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------First off, graphics aren't everything to me. I grew up with Atari, Apple ][e, PowerMacs, NES, and so on. Fallout uses the good old 800x600 overhead isometric view, and does it quite right. The game has a fair amount of variety in the appearance of the locations, though the "cave" areas tend to get a bit too familiar. There is a ton of variety in the objects used, and a lot of areas are just really nice art to look at. It holds up for me, personally. Objectively, it looked great when it came out, but was kind of bashed a bit for not being a light sourced 3D game. Those were the expectations of the time.The best part about the various character models in the game is the way that they are torn apart, melted, disintegrated, exploded and otherwise ended when you discharge your fury on them. The flamethrower is good for laughs, especially. It certainly followed through on the vision of its spiritual predecessor, Wasteland, in that respect. The dialouge sequences with certain characters brings you to a great looking 3D model of the character's animated head, but other wise all characters are rather small and faceless.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SOUND ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The music, combined with the graphics, creates a thick, perfect layer of atmosphere. The desolation and tension of this setting really is emphasized by the great music. Composer Mark Morgan totally nailed it. The various gunshots, laser beams, rockets and explosions of combat all sound great. The 10mm Handgun especially has a very satisfying "THUD" to it.The voice acting is frigging phenominal. Frank Welker, Ron Perlman, Tony Shalhoub, Tress MacNeille, and a bunch more take care of voicing the metric ton of dialouge that exists for all cut scenes and plot "essential" characters. It all sounds so good, you will want to have the sound and music turned up nice and loud while you play. Really, really good.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GAMEPLAY -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Movement while exploring is similar to Diablo, point and click to go. When combat starts, the game switches to turn based mode. This is where how you build your skills and equip your character matters more than how fast you can click on different things. It is possible to gimp your character, and die repeatedly if you don't pay attention to some basic survival needs. Such as at least one strong combat skill, and average intelligence at the very barest of minimums. Intelligence is responsible for getting more points to put into skills when you level up. One or more of your various skills is going to determine your success in pretty much everything you can do in this game. Speech can be a path netting some extra information and reward often enough that I find it useful too. At least a smattering of everything will come in handy, but I personally wouldn't go without lockpick, medicine (for healing and for quests), and science. For combat, anything will do, but bear two things in mind. Be the best. Choose one of the various combat skills, and pump points into it every level until it is at least 75. Then keep rasing it, but it isn't so much of a priority compared to diversity at that point. Smal guns are the most widely available, but don't let that keep you from choosing your own path as they are all viable. It is possible to "play the bad guy" and destroy your karmaic reputation in order to steal, murder, and otherwise plunder the shambles of a society that remains on Earth. Indeed, some quests and items are most easily and quickly performed by stealing something, or locking the door and murdering someone. But, your karma follows you around in this game. At a certain point, you will be unwelcome. Then, people might want to kill you for what you have done. I find that the path of the righteous leads to far greater reward in terms of XP, in this game. There is a wide variety of weapons, armor, enemies, and locations for battle. The battles can play out rather slowly, and being turn based are not everyone's cup of whatever. The game can be rather challenging at the start if you aren't used to these sorts of games, but the difficulty can be changed at any time in game. The game is kind of equal parts combat and exploration. There is a great deal of humor in both, and I have spent plenty of time just watching random NPC's interact with each other. It all piles on to the atmosphere of the fledgling civilization struggling to survive in the harsh new hell they created, only to be found repeating the same death spiral pattern of behaviors that set them on the path in the first place.If you aren't immediately turned off by the graphics and the turn based nature of the game play, then this game might be for you. It is one of the precursors to such games as the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale serieseses.. es. Planescape Torment. Shares team members with Knights of The Old Republic 1 and 2, Fallout New Vegas, Arcanum, and a few more greatest role playing games ever. (KOTOR 2 and Greyhawk have at least been fixed and patched to greatness on PC...) But Fallout and Fallout 2 have always been my very favorites and the most replayed. If you dig a little, you will find that there is a ton of depth and character in this rather slow paced old school game.(Never you mind what the "hours played" on Steam says, my Steam was mostly offline for intermittent years. When I played the game for hundreds of hours since its release, it was the CD-rom version.)

y 12, 2014
												Nostalgia levels over 9000!!!This is the very first PC game I ever purchased. I still own my original disc copy, which is still in perfect condition. I recall in '97 going into my local PX and picking up the retail box from the shelf, and reading the description of the game on the back while deciding my future purchase. Had I known now how much I would come to love this series, I would have bought another copy to keep as a collector's item. Starting up my first game and hearing Ron Perlman's words; "War. War never changes..." still sends chills up my spine to this very day. (By the way he still does the intro narrator voice for the series.)The freedom of choosing your own way to advance in the game was different from most of which I had played at the time. The writing was witty and found my self laughing over some of the more hidden speech options. (Roll a character with a low INT, many LOLS to be had.) I found the combat enjoyable. You can target specific parts of the enemy's body, which allow you to cripple limbs and increasing critical damage. It may seem dated in appearance by today's standards, but makes up for that in quality story and plot. Now go get that water chip vault dweller. Vault 13 depends on you!TL:DR Version: Isometric view RPG with turn based tactical combat - Buy it, enjoy and support the series.

content:
er 18, 2014
												Let me begin by saying i have played every fallout game to date.Fallout is a Open World Post Nuclear Role Playing Game, Which Is Set 80 Years after the Nuclear War which nearly brought an end to mankind there were a few lucky survivors who were able to enter these giant underground Vault's on the day that the bombs dropped, you were born in Vault 13.The Main Story Plot of Fallout is that Your Vaults Water Purification Chip has Broken and that means that The Vault will run out of drinking water very soon so the Vault's Overseer Send's you the Vault Dweller out on a Quest to find a replacement Water Chip.Gameplay in Fallout centers around the game world, visiting locations and interacting with the local inhabitants. Occasionally, inhabitants will be immersed in dilemmas which the player may choose to solve in order to acquire karma and experience points. Fallout deviates from most role-playing video games in that it often allows for the player to complete tasks in multiple ways, often choosing solutions that are unconventional or even contrary to the original task, in which case the player may still be rewarded. The player's actions may ultimately dictate the ending of the game, or what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. Ultimately, players will encounter hostile opponents (if such encounters are not avoided using stealth or diplomacy), in which case they and the player will engage in combat. Non-combat portions of the game are typically played in real-time.Combat in Fallout is turn-based. The game uses an action point system wherein, each turn, multiple actions may be performed until all points in the pool have been expended. Different actions consume different numbers of points, and the maximum number of points that can be spent may be affected by such things as chems or perks. 'Melee' (hand to hand) weapons typically offer multiple attack types, such as 'Swing' and 'Thrust' for knives. Unarmed attacks offer many attack types, including 'Punch' and 'Kick'. Players may equip at most two weapons, and the player can switch between them by clicking a button. The Perception attribute determines characters' 'Sequence' number, which then determines the order of turns in combat; characters with a higher statistic in this attribute will be placed at an earlier position in the sequence of turns, and subsequently get new turns earlier. Perception also determines the maximum range of ranged weapons, and the chance to hit with them.I Would Recomend Fallout To any fan of the Series Or Newcomer.

												One of the best RPGs of all time.The pacing is great, the plot is gripping, the dialogue is awesome (and often hilarious). The graphics still hold up amazingly well for a now 17-year title and the sound effects are spot on. Music is subtle and atmospheric. Not memorable, but does a good job in seting the mood.But what impresses me the most about this game is that it allows for both scripted experience and emergent experiences, as every situation can be remedied through a personally-selected mix of combat, stealth, dialogue.While the game is not as much of a write-your-own as some other open-world games, it leans on the scripted content to create sequences & events that are truly awesome.Good luck in the wastes!

content:
ry 5, 2014
												10/10 - A shining pinnacle of human achievement.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GRAPHICS --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------First off, graphics aren't everything to me. I grew up with Atari, Apple ][e, PowerMacs, NES, and so on. Fallout uses the good old 800x600 overhead isometric view, and does it quite right. The game has a fair amount of variety in the appearance of the locations, though the "cave" areas tend to get a bit too familiar. There is a ton of variety in the objects used, and a lot of areas are just really nice art to look at. It holds up for me, personally. Objectively, it looked great when it came out, but was kind of bashed a bit for not being a light sourced 3D game. Those were the expectations of the time.The best part about the various character models in the game is the way that they are torn apart, melted, disintegrated, exploded and otherwise ended when you discharge your fury on them. The flamethrower is good for laughs, especially. It certainly followed through on the vision of its spiritual predecessor, Wasteland, in that respect. The dialouge sequences with certain characters brings you to a great looking 3D model of the character's animated head, but other wise all characters are rather small and faceless.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SOUND ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The music, combined with the graphics, creates a thick, perfect layer of atmosphere. The desolation and tension of this setting really is emphasized by the great music. Composer Mark Morgan totally nailed it. The various gunshots, laser beams, rockets and explosions of combat all sound great. The 10mm Handgun especially has a very satisfying "THUD" to it.The voice acting is frigging phenominal. Frank Welker, Ron Perlman, Tony Shalhoub, Tress MacNeille, and a bunch more take care of voicing the metric ton of dialouge that exists for all cut scenes and plot "essential" characters. It all sounds so good, you will want to have the sound and music turned up nice and loud while you play. Really, really good.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GAMEPLAY -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Movement while exploring is similar to Diablo, point and click to go. When combat starts, the game switches to turn based mode. This is where how you build your skills and equip your character matters more than how fast you can click on different things. It is possible to gimp your character, and die repeatedly if you don't pay attention to some basic survival needs. Such as at least one strong combat skill, and average intelligence at the very barest of minimums. Intelligence is responsible for getting more points to put into skills when you level up. One or more of your various skills is going to determine your success in pretty much everything you can do in this game. Speech can be a path netting some extra information and reward often enough that I find it useful too. At least a smattering of everything will come in handy, but I personally wouldn't go without lockpick, medicine (for healing and for quests), and science. For combat, anything will do, but bear two things in mind. Be the best. Choose one of the various combat skills, and pump points into it every level until it is at least 75. Then keep rasing it, but it isn't so much of a priority compared to diversity at that point. Smal guns are the most widely available, but don't let that keep you from choosing your own path as they are all viable. It is possible to "play the bad guy" and destroy your karmaic reputation in order to steal, murder, and otherwise plunder the shambles of a society that remains on Earth. Indeed, some quests and items are most easily and quickly performed by stealing something, or locking the door and murdering someone. But, your karma follows you around in this game. At a certain point, you will be unwelcome. Then, people might want to kill you for what you have done. I find that the path of the righteous leads to far greater reward in terms of XP, in this game. There is a wide variety of weapons, armor, enemies, and locations for battle. The battles can play out rather slowly, and being turn based are not everyone's cup of whatever. The game can be rather challenging at the start if you aren't used to these sorts of games, but the difficulty can be changed at any time in game. The game is kind of equal parts combat and exploration. There is a great deal of humor in both, and I have spent plenty of time just watching random NPC's interact with each other. It all piles on to the atmosphere of the fledgling civilization struggling to survive in the harsh new hell they created, only to be found repeating the same death spiral pattern of behaviors that set them on the path in the first place.If you aren't immediately turned off by the graphics and the turn based nature of the game play, then this game might be for you. It is one of the precursors to such games as the Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale serieseses.. es. Planescape Torment. Shares team members with Knights of The Old Republic 1 and 2, Fallout New Vegas, Arcanum, and a few more greatest role playing games ever. (KOTOR 2 and Greyhawk have at least been fixed and patched to greatness on PC...) But Fallout and Fallout 2 have always been my very favorites and the most replayed. If you dig a little, you will find that there is a ton of depth and character in this rather slow paced old school game.(Never you mind what the "hours played" on Steam says, my Steam was mostly offline for intermittent years. When I played the game for hundreds of hours since its release, it was the CD-rom version.)

												One of the best games I have ever played and was surprised to see that it didn't have 99% for positive reviews. So naturally I checked them and can confirm that roughly every negative review was from some retard who didn't so much as look at screenshots, doesn't have any patience whatsoever (I dont even know how you could need patience for this game but people said it was to slow???), and failed to try and even understand how to play the game. Example being "I can never hit anything" Most likely but everything into melee and tried to make eye shots with a gun completely ignoring the % chances to hit specific areas. Normally I would suggest looking at negative reviews because they can point out some huge drawbacks in the game that might make you want to rethink buying it, but in this case they are all pretty much written by ADHD children who wanted a first person shooter (again not a single look at the screenshots).  The only decent one was the top voted one that talked about how this is "slightly" censored and you cant kill children, which I agree is complete bull... You probably want to play with the Fixt mod for this game, basically its a giant patch, doesnt really add anything and the few things it does add are entirely optional. (psst with this you can make your companions move the ♥♥♥♥ out of the door finally). If you truly want to see the game for what it is and get a good idea watch some youtube videos of this game, it is a popular game and has many HD videos with/without clear commentary.Side note: Also dont judge the positive reviews based on time, because with that patch along with the one for fallout 2 you load the game diferently and it doesn't go through steam. Hence fewer hours being shown.

content:
er 2, 2016
												Fallout 1 is an important game for gaming history since without this we wouldn't have to suffer through constant Pop Vinyls and cosplays of Fallout 3 and 4 to capitalise on their success. Despite eventually resulting in one of the worst fanbases of all time, Fallout 1 itself is a masterpiece that deserves to be played by everyone who loves RPGs. I have my fair share of complaints with the original entry, especially in retrospect since Fallout 2 and New Vegas improved upon the formula for the most part, but despite all this Fallout 1 still remains the best written game in the series by far with some of the most memorable locations to ever grace a Fallout game. If I wanted to be really critical I'd complain about things like how the companions have zero depth or how varied you can make the game for yourself in replaying it (in comparison to 2 and NV, 1 still has plenty of variety) but all of that melts away whenever I just sit down and play this game. Fallout 1 isn't perfect but it is so close it's like splitting hairs. If you haven't played this game you owe it to yourself to do it. This remains one of the best RPGs and even best games to this very day.

													It's always hard to dislike a popular game series, but Fallout just isn't for me, which is strange in some ways.  In its defense, I was not paying attention when I bought the game to notice it was a TBS game.  I had some fun in the middle of my experience once I had understood most of the mechanics, but I found it very irritating to get a hold of the controls and basic game play mechanics.  A few walkthroughs later I get further into the game, but I kept running into tedious obstacles that made me have to look up the best actions for them.	I see why people like it, but I am one who couldn't get addicted to it.  I might change my mind if I pick it up and play it in the future.  If anyone has advice on how I might better enjoy the game I am open minded about it.

content:
y 17, 2016
												Fallout is possibly the first game to have a wide variety of choices and consequences. (and perks/traits.) And it shouldn't be played just because it's the first to do it, but because it does it very well.It starts with a simple premise: You live in an underground nuclear fallout shelter (aka, a Vault) 80 years after a two-hour war between China and the US basically ended up in the both countries getting wholly nuked, and the water chip that keeps a supply of water to the whole Vault was damaged, and you were the unlucky one to have to venture out into the outside world to find the closest Vault and get another chip to save everyone you know. You are expelled into a cave full of rats (the ultimate and classic RPG enemy) and have to venture out, the first of your Vault to do so.Fallout's system, SPECIAL, was made in a week (with the exception of perks), and it shows. The original goal of the team, when the game still had a license for GURPS (another system) was that no skill or stat should be useless. Well, first tip to creating a character: dump Charisma and get 4 free stat points. There are also a lot of mostly useless skills, but anyone with half a brain should distinguish the useless from the useful.Combat is nothing special, except for the gory death animations: When getting crits with different weapons, enemies (or you) will die in very elaborate deaths: getting cut in half by the sheer amount of bullet holes a burst fire of a mini-gun has gave you, for example! It's pretty fun, even though the combat itself lacks tactical depth (sure, you can aim at limbs, eyes and crotch, but you'll end up shooting eyes always - well, maybe crotch for some amusing banter :))It's not a very long game, but throughout it you venture through several settlements that have been built   by the surivivors of California. You will have several multi-pathed quests and consequences, though, sadly, most of the consequences are only showed in the slideshow at the end of the game. Still, you will feel that your choices matter. The atmosphere is great, with no small influence of the great ambient soundtrack Mark Morgan produced, and the game gets better the more you progress into it: The final two areas have the most different ways of approaching the obstacles presented, and the game ends with one of the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ "final bosses" of game history, if you choose to not kill him directly: You talk him out of doing spoiler , but your speech skill won't do it alone. You'll have to find evidence that convinces him. And then, you will be shown what you could and couldn't do. On the first playthrough, unless you got lucky, you will end up having failed to save a lot of people.Well, how about a replay?

content:
ber 15, 2015
												It feels weird to give a thumbs up to a game I just can't seem to get through, but as always with my more contentious reviews - this is the fault of a system that doesn't allow a rating scale.I'll put it this way - if you can get over an incredibly dated interface and graphical style, and can deal with potentially looking up some information online (self-guided tutorial) you may find some fun here. The game offers a rich top-down old-school RPG experience. I would say you should watch a gameplay video, check out the screenshots, if you're not put off by anything you see it's probably for you. If you're looking for something approaching this experience from modern games, Wasteland 2 offers a similar setting in the same mechanical style but with updated graphics and features, while the new Fallout games offer similar tone and stories with differing mechanics (first person). Wary of problems from previous attempts, I am happy to report that it runs considerably better now on Windows 10 than it ever did for me on Windows 7. I've had none of the crashing or strange graphic bugs that plagued my last attempt at the game, but it is still so dated that without a nostalgic pull it's difficult for me to really get into. I am shelving it for now until I get in a real 90's mood - in which case I will come back and edit my review.

content:
7, 2014
												+Great game, lotta fun once you figure out the combat system+Learn a lot about the Fallout universe that you wouldn't know from only playing 3 or New Vegas, such as what happened at other Vaults, the origins of things like super-mutants and Raiders+Awesome weapons+Turn-based combat is tough and always keeps you on your toes+Enemies are scarier as a result+As far as I know, you can't become an invincible god like in 3 and New Vegas which gives you a sense of humility+Which also forces you to fight cautiously, strategically and pick your battles+Random events are either positive or negative so you're hopeful, yet cautious when traveling+In-game time is important, which gives a sense of immersion+In-game time isn't too fast or too slow, it's just right+It also goes into much more vivid detail than most games, there's an in-game calendar and things happen on certain dates, most games do night/day like , occasionally you'll see a game that does time of the day or day of the week+No fast traveling like in 3 or New Vegas. Instead of pulling up your Pip Boy and selecting a place, you have to actually leave your current city, then travel to the next. You're shown a map of the whole area and once you click somewhere, your guy moves as in-game time flies by at a realistic and believable pace. You also slow down at mountains and stuff, to make it seem more like you're climbing them. Occasionally, you get a random event which stops your traveling and gives you more of a feeling like your actually adventuring-Combat system is hard to get used to-Enemies can be a bit too tough at times-If there are too many enemies, you're going to die, no matter how much skill or luck you possess-If there are enough NPCs during a battle, you have to wait forever for your turn as each NPC moves and attacks one at a time, especially during missions where you help escort the Crimson Caravan-During such battle, I bet I could walk away from my computer, make a sandwich, and come back and still be waiting for my turn-Turn based combat is annoying and confusing before you learn how it works, which is not easy because it isn't self-explanatory in any way+/- Even though it's Fallout, it has a completely different feel if you're like most Fallout players if you've only played 3 or New Vegas. I like this fact, but I can imagine that others wouldn't+/- Neurtal NPCs react to you unholstering your weapon. From a realism point of view, it makes sense, but from a gameplay point of view, it can be annoying

content:
er 21, 2013
												“The struggle for survival is a war without end. And war… war never changes.”Fallout is one of those rare role-playing games oozing quality from every pore – one might even say radiate. The gameplay is smooth, using action points for movement and combat. In addition it has one of the best character development systems you can wish for. The amazing story, great love for detail and high replayability make for an excellent gaming experience.Fun fact: Fallouts retro-futurism has been inspired by 1950s pulp magazines, superhero comics of Atomic Age and classic Science Fiction films such as Forbidden Planet. There are also many references to the events and the style of Wasteland (PC game from 1988) in the Fallout series, which is why Fallout is sometimes regarded as a spiritual successor to Wasteland.--My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:-	Atmosphere-	Characters-	Details-	Tactical gameplay-	Story-	Combat & ControlsBased on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading: -	S-Rank: excellent-	A-Rank: very good-	B-Rank: solid-	C-Rank: satisfactory-	D-Rank: inferiorIf the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).--Atmosphere: S-Rank(I am the bringer of death! Fall to your knees and beg for mercy… or give me a sandwich, I’m pretty hungry.)Characters: S-Rank (Do I have to sacrifice a puppy to join?)Details: S-Rank (To see a valley filled with my enemies’ heads mounted on spears. A silent valley, except for the wind whistling through their ears.)Tactical gameplay: S-Rank (Don’t drink glowing water.)Story: S-Rank (There is a bad place where the bad mutants come from. It is bad. Vault is good. Please, go and destroy bad place.)Combat & Controls: S-Rank (Excuse me while I gloat…)--There are no achievements to conquer.Achievement difficulty: none--Fallout: New Vegas (PC) – Action role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2010 -Fallout 3 (PC) – Action role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2008-Fallout Tactics: Brotherhood of Steel (PC) – Squad-based strategy game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 2001http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197968514473/recommended/38420/-Fallout 2 (PC) – Turn-based role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 1998http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561197968514473/recommended/38410/-Fallout 1 (PC) – Turn-based role-playing game (Post-apocalyptic Science Fiction) – 1997
