That good.1 cup all-purpose flour, (spooned and leveled)2 tablespoons sugar2 teaspoons baking powder1/2 teaspoon salt1 cup milk2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted, or vegetable oil1 large egg1 tablespoon vegetable oilAssorted toppings, such as butter, maple syrup, confectioners' sugar, honey, jams, preserves, sweetened whipped cream, or chocolate syrupPreheat oven to 200 degrees; have a baking sheet or heatproof platter ready to keep cooked pancakes warm in the oven. In a small bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt; set aside.In a medium bowl, whisk together milk, butter (or oil), and egg. Add dry ingredients to milk mixture; whisk until just moistened (do not overmix; a few small lumps are fine).Heat a large skillet (nonstick or cast-iron) or griddle over medium. Fold a sheet of paper towel in half, and moisten with oil; carefully rub skillet with oiled paper towel.For each pancake, spoon 2 to 3 tablespoons of batter onto skillet, using the back of the spoon to spread batter into a round (you should be able to fit 2 to 3 in a large skillet).Cook until surface of pancakes have some bubbles and a few have burst, 1 to 2 minutes. Flip carefully with a thin spatula, and cook until browned on the underside, 1 to 2 minutes more. Transfer to a baking sheet or platter; cover loosely with aluminum foil, and keep warm in oven. Continue with more oil and remaining batter. (You'll have 12 to 15 pancakes.) Serve warm, with desired toppings.

content:
7, 2015
												One of the best RPGs ever created, and the first game in one of the greatest game series of all time. If you're a fan of Fallout 3 or Fallout: New Vegas, you need to play Fallout & Fallout 2. If you're a fan of RPGs, you need to play Fallout, if you're a fan of original, immersive, interesting, and amusing games with interesting characters, quests, worlds, and items, you need to play Fallout. The biggest complaint I hear people give Fallout and Fallout 2 is that they're "outdated" and that they've aged terribly, when this simply isn't the case. And what's worse, is that I hear this from people who supposedly claim to be HUGE Fallout fans. Fallout: New Vegas is my favorite Fallout game becuase it combines the skillful writing, RPG elements, and interesting characters and places from Fallout and Fallout 2, AND the first/third-person 3D open-world that I am used to, but even then I'm still able to turn off my FPS fanboy goggles for a little while to play an Isometric turn-based RPG because I love Fallout. I just really can't understand, if you really love Fallout, how any of the supposedly "outdated" elements of the original two games can hinder you from enjoying them, grow a pair and play them, It's not that difficult.Compared to Fallout 2, Fallout is probably a little lacking, as Fallout 2 practically improves in every single aspect of the game, a larger game world with more quests, more people to meet and more places to explore, however, the only thing FO2 doesn't really improve upon was the somewhat "serious" tone in the original, as Fallout 2 makes Fallout look like Heavy Rain in comparison. Although I myself prefer Fallout 2 for the reasons listed above, the original is still one of the greatest RPGs of all time, and of course, the forerunner for the complete Fallout series, which, for good or bad, is still going strong today. Also, don't give Ian the SMG.R.I.P. Ian, died while rescuing Tandi from the Raiders.R.I.P. Tycho, died while cleansing the Deathclaws from the Warehouse.R.I.P. Dogmeat, died while eradicating the Super Mutants from the Watershed.R.I.P. Katja, died while fighting the Super Mutants in the LA Vault.PS, game can actually run on Windows 7, *cough* Fallout 3 *cough*

In a small bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt; set aside.In a medium bowl, whisk together milk, butter (or oil), and egg. Add dry ingredients to milk mixture; whisk until just moistened (do not overmix; a few small lumps are fine).Heat a large skillet (nonstick or cast-iron) or griddle over medium. Fold a sheet of paper towel in half, and moisten with oil; carefully rub skillet with oiled paper towel.For each pancake, spoon 2 to 3 tablespoons of batter onto skillet, using the back of the spoon to spread batter into a round (you should be able to fit 2 to 3 in a large skillet).Cook until surface of pancakes have some bubbles and a few have burst, 1 to 2 minutes. Flip carefully with a thin spatula, and cook until browned on the underside, 1 to 2 minutes more. Transfer to a baking sheet or platter; cover loosely with aluminum foil, and keep warm in oven. Continue with more oil and remaining batter. (You'll have 12 to 15 pancakes.) Serve warm, with desired toppings.

												My introduction to the Fallout series was Fallout 3. I had never heard of the series before that, but after a few months (because I wasn't paying much attention to the community) I heard long time fans of the series were upset with how Bethesda handled the game. I wasn't completely disillusioned with Bethesda yet at this time and I hadn't started looking at things more critically, so I didn't understand the problem back then. I also had nothing else to compare it to at the time.Then Fallout: New Vegas came and it was better than FO3 in every way. Then Fallout 4 came and it was worse than about anything I could compare it to in very nearly every way. During this time I had tried to get into Fallout 1 a number of times, but never really did, farthest I had made it was to Shady Sands before quitting. Until this past week, that is. According to Steam I've played about 18 hours in the past week and I'm really loving it so far and I can see why so many long time fans have an issue with Fallout 3 and 4.

content:
er 16, 2015
												For those of you who got this game after playing 3, New Vegas and/or 4, prepare for a whole different cup of tea.This game is a isometric top down RPG(in case you didnt see the screenshots) and is a game that does not hold your hand whatsoever.And this being an older Fallout game means.....1) No tutorials and you are just thrown into the game straight.2) No quest markers meaning you might bang your head trying to find the correct location.3) You have to figure things out on your own.4) You have to save frequently lest you lose progress.5) Combat is significantly different that what you are used in future Fallouts, being slow and tactical.6) Inventory management and bartering is more cumbersome.7) Movement and exploration is slow with random encounters of random difficulty.If any of those turn you off then I suggest you rethink your purchase. Other than that, the game has a compelling story, great characters and quests to take on, its pretty much what you expect from the Fallout games, you are tasked with a huge responsibility and you set out to explore the wasteland. Its a very good game for its time and if you can get over the old game tropes I listed above, you are gonna have a good time.And look.....just be safe out there...ok.

content:
er 29, 2013
												Wow, where do I begin? You can probably tell by looking at my profile picture that I'm a fan of this particular franchise. Let me tell you a story about how my Fallout journey began... Back when I was a young lad, I was thumbing through a gaming mag (believe it or not, that's what we had to do before the internet exploded) and saw a page dedicated to Fallout 2, with some screenshots and synopsis, etc. 'This is interesting' I thought to myself, fresh off the high that I got from playing Metal Gear Solid and Final Fantasy VII; I was excited for more deep, mature and thought-provoking games. But then I noticed that it was a computer game, which is, sadly, rather hard to play when you don't have a computer. So I let it go. Fast forward a year or two later and there's a new PC in the den, but by then I had already forgotten about that obscure magazine article... But luckily, later that year on my 17th birthday, I was in a retail store looking for ways to waste my money. While walking toward the Playstation aisle I passed by a small section dedicated to PC games. It was a pathetic display, mostly consisting of FMV puzzle games and flight sims. But then I saw it... like a black hole pulsing with darkness and malice... Fallout 1 and 2, together, for a mere $10. I looked over my shoulder to verify that no one was watching as I picked up the M-rated game(s), one of the few I placed my hands on. There was a stigma attatched to M-rated games, back before they were making billions, and they were few and far between. The mere sight of the M was enough to make parents cringe. Thanks to Mortal Kombat and Doom, there was the notion that these games were evil and soul-stealing. So as I gazed with awe at the box art, I was thankful that my brother had driven me to the store and not my mother. I took it to the counter, and for the first and last time ever, I was asked to show my ID for the purchase. I was nervous, but I was 17, so there was nothing they could do to stop me.I waited until my parents had gone to bed before installing the game. I had an idea of what to expect, but I admit I was still trying to wrap my head around the concept of a world where the Jestons-inspired retro version of the future was true, and the cold war turned into a nuclear reality. I had never heard of such nonsense in my life, but somehow, it made perfect sense. 'War never changes'... the haunting opening entered into my mind and settled comfortably, as if my mind had already decided that this was going to be something special. And Oh, how it was, and is... Fallout is brilliant. A dark, atmospheric, violent and oddly loveable adventure into a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Taking inspiration from the Road Warrior and twisting it into something grand and absurd. I won't go into anything specific about the story and setting, because by this point, 15 years later, you may already know enough. If not, you are in for a treat. I would say that it still holds up, but that's because I got in when it was still pretty new, so my perspective is a bit skewed. What I will say is that still, to this day, even with all the amazing advancements in games, it has some things about it that have yet to be surpassed. The exceptionally well-concieved levelling system, for example, is probably the best there has ever been in a game of any kind.   I could spend another hour writing about why I love this game so much, but if you are one of those people that have yet to experience it, I think it best you go in with as little information as possible. I can not recommend this game enough; It is truly a masterpiece that every RPG fan should know by heart.

content:
8, 2015
												So I recently replayed this game for the first time since the 90's. Here's what I think now, without the nostalgia glasses on.Funny, slow, a bit repetitive but charming story.I probably killed the fun in this game when I figured out an exploit. I like to set my LUCK to 10 at the start of the game so I can more easily get the random event with the UFO. The UFO blast gun is hands down the most powerful gun in this game and it's the only thing you need to be successful. It's lightweight, holds tons of ammo and destroys everything you throw at it. Make sure to dump a ton of points into ENERGY weapons at the start and buy ammo from the hub. Another thing I did that I guess could be considered cheating was I boosted my gambling skill to around 60-70%. I gambled in the hub and the chance of you winning over losing is greater. I took 2 iPhones and postioned them on the keyboard to hold down 1 and 3 on the keyboard I believe. It forces the game to continue gambling rapidly. After 30 minutes I came back to discover I now have 250,000 bottlecaps!Anyways, the point I'm trying to get at is this game is pretty flexible and has some really unique elements you're not going to find anywhere else. I personally prefer this game and FO2 over the new Fallout games. I don't think Bethesda really fully grasped this franchise and how it's supposed to feel. +I'm a big fan of the SPECIAL system.+Combat is a bit lackluster but it works.+Make sure to speed up combat in options, otherwise companions will annoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.+Dogmeat companion.+The ending boss is hilarious and well worth the journey. Make sure to watch all of his responses on Youtube.-I wasn't a big fan of all they portrayed your vault. I think it would've been better to never have the ability to re-enter the vault 13 so your imagination can go crazy for how it should be in there.

content:
3, 2014
												Released back in 1997, Fallout is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to Wasteland with heavy influences from the 1981 movie Mad Max, this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just ♥♥♥♥ someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll ♥♥♥♥, so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real ♥♥♥♥ happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time. The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way, Fallout carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in Fallout: New Vegas. There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. First, there are major graphical bugs which can be fixed, but may persist nonetheless in more benign forms, which is to be expected of a game that's almost seventeen years old. Then there's some other annoying nitpicks, like unintuitive UI that feels clunky and the odd limitation like not being able to move more than 999 bottle caps at a time when bartering. The AI can be absolute garbage at times, too. Let's put it this way. There were times when I felt grateful that one of my followers was standing in a corner and not fighting, because that means he couldn't shoot me in the back. Without the ability to control your party, things can get pretty frustrating later in the game, when you're rolling with a huge posse to beat the final boss. Hint: save often, and in many slots.So, would I reccomend this game? That depends. Are you looking for an old school CRPG with deep combat and meaningful choices and character growth? If so, then I'll be damned if you can find a better game than Fallout.

content:
8, 2015
												So I recently replayed this game for the first time since the 90's. Here's what I think now, without the nostalgia glasses on.Funny, slow, a bit repetitive but charming story.I probably killed the fun in this game when I figured out an exploit. I like to set my LUCK to 10 at the start of the game so I can more easily get the random event with the UFO. The UFO blast gun is hands down the most powerful gun in this game and it's the only thing you need to be successful. It's lightweight, holds tons of ammo and destroys everything you throw at it. Make sure to dump a ton of points into ENERGY weapons at the start and buy ammo from the hub. Another thing I did that I guess could be considered cheating was I boosted my gambling skill to around 60-70%. I gambled in the hub and the chance of you winning over losing is greater. I took 2 iPhones and postioned them on the keyboard to hold down 1 and 3 on the keyboard I believe. It forces the game to continue gambling rapidly. After 30 minutes I came back to discover I now have 250,000 bottlecaps!Anyways, the point I'm trying to get at is this game is pretty flexible and has some really unique elements you're not going to find anywhere else. I personally prefer this game and FO2 over the new Fallout games. I don't think Bethesda really fully grasped this franchise and how it's supposed to feel. +I'm a big fan of the SPECIAL system.+Combat is a bit lackluster but it works.+Make sure to speed up combat in options, otherwise companions will annoy the ♥♥♥♥ out of you.+Dogmeat companion.+The ending boss is hilarious and well worth the journey. Make sure to watch all of his responses on Youtube.-I wasn't a big fan of all they portrayed your vault. I think it would've been better to never have the ability to re-enter the vault 13 so your imagination can go crazy for how it should be in there.

content:
ber 28, 2012
												I played this game to completion in 2001 when it was only available on cd-rom. Since then I purchased copies on GoG.com and Steam.Fallout is the standard by which every other entry in the franchise should be judged. It is the more focused, balanced, thematically coherent Fallout experience available and the only one released with main designers Tim Cain, Leonard Boyarsky and Jason Anderson still on board.By today's standards the game still hold up well even without fan patches and resolution mods, which are still strongly recommended. The engine and interface does show its age and the sequel, Fallout 2, improves a few things here and there. But the turn-based system and top down camera are not products of their times. First person view and real time combat are not "modern". Changing the former for the latter doesn't constitute an improvement, but a complete change of direction.This kind of game wasn't made that way due to technical limitations. Bethesda released its first Elder Scrolls game in 1994, the year Tim Cain started working on what would become Fallout. No, the intention was to make a computer rpg that felt like playing a pen & paper role playing game. It wasn't about player skills, but player choices. The perspective is from someone playing Dongeons & Dragons, Shadowrun or (more appropriately) GURPS, seeing the world through the maps and descriptions provided by the game master and, ultimately, interpreted by the player's imagination.It isn't the most popular perspective but a legitimate one nonetheless, which suits computer rpgs like a glove. This is how Fallout was meant to be played and, frankly, that's how it should have stayed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
												Released back in 1997, Fallout is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to Wasteland with heavy influences from the 1981 movie Mad Max, this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just ♥♥♥♥ someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll ♥♥♥♥, so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real ♥♥♥♥ happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time. The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way, Fallout carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in Fallout: New Vegas. There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. First, there are major graphical bugs which can be fixed, but may persist nonetheless in more benign forms, which is to be expected of a game that's almost seventeen years old. Then there's some other annoying nitpicks, like unintuitive UI that feels clunky and the odd limitation like not being able to move more than 999 bottle caps at a time when bartering. The AI can be absolute garbage at times, too. Let's put it this way. There were times when I felt grateful that one of my followers was standing in a corner and not fighting, because that means he couldn't shoot me in the back. Without the ability to control your party, things can get pretty frustrating later in the game, when you're rolling with a huge posse to beat the final boss. Hint: save often, and in many slots.So, would I reccomend this game? That depends. Are you looking for an old school CRPG with deep combat and meaningful choices and character growth? If so, then I'll be damned if you can find a better game than Fallout.

												This is the original Fallout. If you're not farmilar with it this game is a post-apocalyptic turn-based RPG and wildly regarded as a classic. but I'm not in love with it. I say this as someone who is fairly young and dosen't have a notalgia bias twords this game as I was growing up.To start, this game is very well made and, other than the graphics, the game has aged very well. It plays like it should and has an amazing atmosphere.You may hear about the graphics glitching out on newer systems, however this is nolonger true. Bethesda recently patched the game so it works on newer systems. If you are using an older system you still have the option to play the classic version. The new version (to my knowledge) is the same as the classic version with the exception of the graphics being fixed.All in all if you want to play the game that launched the Fallout series, are looking for a nostalgia trip, or enjoy this kind of game I highly recomend it. There are no real problems, I wouldn't say it's perfect, but it definatly does it's job. For that, I recomend this game.

												The Fallout series has been known for it's great exploration, looting fun, and character progression as you endure many different radioactive wastelands. But I think that Fallout 1 is by far the most immersive of them all. Although it's late 90's graphics are nothing compared to the modern graphic card melting games, this game's experience is told through reading, dialogue, scrounging for information, and plain old exploration. This game gives a more vivid and detailed image of what the reality of a open wasteland filled with murder and death feels lke than any other fallout's even come close to. That's more than enough reason to pick this game up, especially now that you can play it without uninstalling windows, thanks to Bethesda's new hi-resolution update!

content:
er 16, 2015
												For those of you who got this game after playing 3, New Vegas and/or 4, prepare for a whole different cup of tea.This game is a isometric top down RPG(in case you didnt see the screenshots) and is a game that does not hold your hand whatsoever.And this being an older Fallout game means.....1) No tutorials and you are just thrown into the game straight.2) No quest markers meaning you might bang your head trying to find the correct location.3) You have to figure things out on your own.4) You have to save frequently lest you lose progress.5) Combat is significantly different that what you are used in future Fallouts, being slow and tactical.6) Inventory management and bartering is more cumbersome.7) Movement and exploration is slow with random encounters of random difficulty.If any of those turn you off then I suggest you rethink your purchase. Other than that, the game has a compelling story, great characters and quests to take on, its pretty much what you expect from the Fallout games, you are tasked with a huge responsibility and you set out to explore the wasteland. Its a very good game for its time and if you can get over the old game tropes I listed above, you are gonna have a good time.And look.....just be safe out there...ok.

												My introduction to the Fallout series was Fallout 3. I had never heard of the series before that, but after a few months (because I wasn't paying much attention to the community) I heard long time fans of the series were upset with how Bethesda handled the game. I wasn't completely disillusioned with Bethesda yet at this time and I hadn't started looking at things more critically, so I didn't understand the problem back then. I also had nothing else to compare it to at the time.Then Fallout: New Vegas came and it was better than FO3 in every way. Then Fallout 4 came and it was worse than about anything I could compare it to in very nearly every way. During this time I had tried to get into Fallout 1 a number of times, but never really did, farthest I had made it was to Shady Sands before quitting. Until this past week, that is. According to Steam I've played about 18 hours in the past week and I'm really loving it so far and I can see why so many long time fans have an issue with Fallout 3 and 4.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2016
												The game hasn't aged well, but I could see it being big back when it was released. This is the game that started it all before Bethedsa took over the series and made Fallout 3. The gameplay mechanics thus are vastly different from the more recent titles. For one thing, you play in a top down perspective and basically attack enemies during turn based combat. However, you can move your character around freely during your turn so it's not as restricted as other turn based games. You also have various RPG elements such as stats you can improve, loot and inventory, and different outcomes based on your dialogue choices. I like the amount of freedom the game gives you since you can pretty much play the game how you want. There's a good amount of side quests that you can do if you want and the lore is there if you're interested in that stuff. What I don't like about the game is two things: the interface and the combat speed. The interface can take some getting used to because moving your character around, accessing weapons/inventory, etc. is done in an unconventional manner in my opinion. Also, the combat in this game can take forever especially if you are facing multiple enemies. This is because the characters move so slow when they walk and going through all the animations can end up making a large battle take 15-30 minutes. I wouldn't recommend this game to people who haven't played old 90s PC games before because like I said the interface and the combat mechanics can ruin the experience for you. However if you want the full Fallout experience this is where it all started.

content:
er 29, 2013
												Wow, where do I begin? You can probably tell by looking at my profile picture that I'm a fan of this particular franchise. Let me tell you a story about how my Fallout journey began... Back when I was a young lad, I was thumbing through a gaming mag (believe it or not, that's what we had to do before the internet exploded) and saw a page dedicated to Fallout 2, with some screenshots and synopsis, etc. 'This is interesting' I thought to myself, fresh off the high that I got from playing Metal Gear Solid and Final Fantasy VII; I was excited for more deep, mature and thought-provoking games. But then I noticed that it was a computer game, which is, sadly, rather hard to play when you don't have a computer. So I let it go. Fast forward a year or two later and there's a new PC in the den, but by then I had already forgotten about that obscure magazine article... But luckily, later that year on my 17th birthday, I was in a retail store looking for ways to waste my money. While walking toward the Playstation aisle I passed by a small section dedicated to PC games. It was a pathetic display, mostly consisting of FMV puzzle games and flight sims. But then I saw it... like a black hole pulsing with darkness and malice... Fallout 1 and 2, together, for a mere $10. I looked over my shoulder to verify that no one was watching as I picked up the M-rated game(s), one of the few I placed my hands on. There was a stigma attatched to M-rated games, back before they were making billions, and they were few and far between. The mere sight of the M was enough to make parents cringe. Thanks to Mortal Kombat and Doom, there was the notion that these games were evil and soul-stealing. So as I gazed with awe at the box art, I was thankful that my brother had driven me to the store and not my mother. I took it to the counter, and for the first and last time ever, I was asked to show my ID for the purchase. I was nervous, but I was 17, so there was nothing they could do to stop me.I waited until my parents had gone to bed before installing the game. I had an idea of what to expect, but I admit I was still trying to wrap my head around the concept of a world where the Jestons-inspired retro version of the future was true, and the cold war turned into a nuclear reality. I had never heard of such nonsense in my life, but somehow, it made perfect sense. 'War never changes'... the haunting opening entered into my mind and settled comfortably, as if my mind had already decided that this was going to be something special. And Oh, how it was, and is... Fallout is brilliant. A dark, atmospheric, violent and oddly loveable adventure into a post-apocalyptic wasteland. Taking inspiration from the Road Warrior and twisting it into something grand and absurd. I won't go into anything specific about the story and setting, because by this point, 15 years later, you may already know enough. If not, you are in for a treat. I would say that it still holds up, but that's because I got in when it was still pretty new, so my perspective is a bit skewed. What I will say is that still, to this day, even with all the amazing advancements in games, it has some things about it that have yet to be surpassed. The exceptionally well-concieved levelling system, for example, is probably the best there has ever been in a game of any kind.   I could spend another hour writing about why I love this game so much, but if you are one of those people that have yet to experience it, I think it best you go in with as little information as possible. I can not recommend this game enough; It is truly a masterpiece that every RPG fan should know by heart.

content:
er 2, 2013
												It's Worth It, Just Be Prepared to Mod ItFallout's strengths lie in two areas: atmosphere and customization. The atmosphere of Fallout is amazing. It's one of the few games I feel that has gotten its atmosphere down right, combining a dangerous and barren post-apocalyptia with a retro 1950s undertone, and maintains a great balance between feeling ridiculous and serious. The story isn't anything to write home about, but it's an effective motivating force for the game. With that in mind, know that if you pick up Fallout, do NOT consult any walkthrough or wiki when playing it because, trust me, it'll spoil the fun. Fallout is the type of RPG that's made a whole lot better when you live with your consequences and aren't certain about where the story will take you. As for the customization, Fallout has it in plentiful supply and I'm not just refering to the moral choices available to you. Rather, it's the character customization which is some of the best. Between getting to specialize in a wide variety of weapon types to being able to having your intelligence level effect your choices in the game (Anything below an Intelligence of 4 makes you a bumbling idiot, and this is reflected in game by your dialogue options which are limited to "me have trouble thinking") there's a great amount of replayability to this game. However, while I recommend Fallout it does come with a bundle of bugs, some of which have the potential to be game breaking such as being trapped in a corner by an unmovable companion NPC. Because of this, I recommend you mod it. My personal recommendation is called "Fallout FIXT" by Sduibek. It's a great megamod which fixes a lot of problems, and is VERY customizable allowing you to choose between general bug fixes and improvements, or changing the feel of the game entirely. It's a great download. Anyway, Fallout is a fantastic (though not a perfect) game. I highly recommend it, ESPECIALLY if you can bag it for cheap!

ber 30, 2014
												Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: HighBudget: Worth it if you're a fan only as the game is very old and dated. If you have no knowledge of the game, don't bother throwing a cent at it. Lenght: Unknown. At least a week. Probably more. Fallout is an old classic. If you've played fallout 3 or New Vegas and taken an interest in the series and want to try this, I seriously recommend watching a few youtube vids first, as the game is very old. It's not exactly easy to adjust to a game this dated. That said, even on windows 7, it plays without error. The game will probably remind a lot of people, initially of the more recent fallout games. They seem do have done a great job of passing on the setting. Bear in mind that this is turn-based combat, and top-down view and isometric. It's truly an oldie. The game is crafted with a lot of detail in mind. Each map allows for every single item to be examined, and unlike in more recent RPG's in general, you will not be told when to use skills. There is no tutorial (to my knowledge) but the game isn't super hard to figure out, and if it becomes tricky there are guides on the internet. It's a good holiday project, but hardly a treat for a gamer who seeks a visual challenge and revolutionary gameplay. For gamers interested in gaming history or people in general who can stand playing old games, you will have a chance to experience a rolepalying game that dates to the time when people really knew how to craft a world with eye for detail. Personally I tried fallout when I was a child, having barely a clue what I was doing. I've since stumbled on it again and again with friends who time and time again referred to it as a classic. It truly is.

												EDITED (rewritten) : the negative mark is explained below*, but the game is original, good and fun in terms of RPG adventure and freedom of movement.WARNING : once you are aware that the saved games tend to break, you can avoid much frustration.  How: save your current game in many slots and never save in Combat mode (even if there is no actual combat, do not save in that stance or mode).On a technical level, the game is a bit painful, but you can greatly make it more player-friendly and more fun with the version called "Fallout Fixt" : independant programmers and modders have combined to allow a much better experience (source: nma-fallout.com ).  For example, the 'Fixt' version allows to control the companions directly (!), pressing ESC closes most windows, etc. * When you sell a game on Steam for 10 $, without giving a warning about a game breaking bug (that can be circumvented), it is not ethical nor honorable.  I am told that the original company no longer exist, but someone is making money now.  Everything can be justified with logic or reason, but I don't accept that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  The game has been improved many times back then, but the game breaking save bug remains (i.e. they could just block the possibility of saving in combat mode for example).  The game is worth it once you know that.

y 6
												I love Fallout 2 that game rocks and I really recommend playing it if you want to experience what Fallout games, in my opinion, are really meant to be. But Fallout 1... I just can't get into.(tl;dr at the bottom)My problem with Fallout one is the water chip an Item that forces you to go and find it in 150 days. In theory this sounds great, an object that forces you from one location to another in a certain amount of time that makes sure that you aren't straying. But the execution is horrible, I found myself with a crap ton of towns unlocked early into the game. This resulted in me traveling to a nearby one and finding out that a water chip "apparently" in a town that is 5 day days travel form where I currently am and resulted in me going there and finding out that there are freaking super mutants in the place in which Im searching for the water chip. So I proceed to turn around and go to the brotherhood of steel which is a 10-15 day travel from where I am as that sounds like a place where I would find a water chip. When I get there I am told to go to "The glow" which is 10 days there and 10 days back and retrieve and item. When I do that they let me in, and guess what they don't have a water chip. So now I am sitting at 53 days left as I also made Detours to other towns to do crap.tl;drBut enough rambling I will just get to the point. Fallout 2 was fun because it gave you more freedom and all the the time in the world, as thirteen years is enough to do everything in the game 5X over.Fallout 1 on the other hand, while smaller in scale forces you to play it's pace rather then yours and gives you a small amount of time to do everything. If Fallout one was my first old school Fallout game I would have just dropped the series entirely and never picked it up again.edit:spelling

Forget the F3/NV; Fallout 1 (and Fallout 2) is how the post-apocalyptic world could actually look like.Harshness, seriousness and darkness of the post-apocalyptic world? It's in it.Humour, hyperbole, light tone and pop-culture references? It's in there, without diminishing the serious tone of the game.INCREDIBLE dialogues and your possibilities in it. Great music, fits the atmosphere perfectly. Decent storyline. The number of possibilities on how you could play through this game is uncountable. You can beat this game in 9 minutes 17 seconds (literally, speedrun is on youtube somewhere) or in average 20 hours without getting bored for 1 second. For me it's possibly the best RPG out there.New Fallouts were decent games but sh*t-tier Fallouts. You want to know why is Fallout considered one of the best RPG series ever? Play this (or Fallout 2) and forget the sequels for now.↑ all of this applies to Fallout 2 as well

content:
6, 2012
												For all its weeping sores, the best PC game of the 1990s except for Homeworld, and probably the best RPG on Steam. Lots of freedom, likeable characters, an intriguing backstory, a main quest you can straight-up fail, some of the greatest endings in any game, and a gorgeous dark-ambient soundtrack.On the down side, the interface is clunky and slow, especially inventory. NPC sidekicks can be frustrating to work with and will often harm you or each other. (It's not nearly as bad as some clumsy players will tell you it is.) And a few quests can hinge on pixel hunting - not intentionally, but simply because items can be hard to spot against the dithery backgrounds.Be advised that all combat in this game is turn-based. It's fun, but it's NOT optional like you see in Fallout 3 and New Vegas. You will take turns spending action points on a hex grid, every fight. Fallout is a slow RPG. It is not by any definition an action game.Highest possible recommendation.

content:
r 30, 2015
												=--------REVIEW SYNOPSIS-------------=Ah... the classic. It's ancient... very old. Despite that however, Bethesda still shows love to this timeless classic created by Fallout's original makers; Interplay. This is the one that started them all. It hasn't aged well as far as graphics and gameplay goes, but it's true to the RPG format, and one of the original US Turn-based RPGs from the 90s era. It spans the entireity of the Mojave Dersert-region... more precisely, the deserts of the California and Nevada regions. You begin as a Lone Wanderer set upon a quest to restore your Vault-Tek™ Vault's water chip; the sole thing that purifies the disease-ridden, irradiated waters of the surface world so that your vault's inhabitants will have fresh water to drink. It having broken down, you're sent out to find a new one. Along the way, you'll encounter many strange people... and many deadly enemies, not-so interesting companions... but companions none-the-less.=--------PROGRESSIVE POINTS----------=*Elder to the first US-based RPGs*Turn-based (You are free to plan your next move, it could be your last!)*Compatability/Optimized for Windows 7+ Operating Systems*Compatability/Still contains the original version for 98/XP-based Operating Systems*Brutal difficulty (Just how you remember it)=--------CONTRARY POINTS-------------=*Ancient graphical detail*Linear storyline*Limited range of weaponry/gear*Brutal difficulty (No forgiveness for mistakes)*Clunky UI (For what it was back in the day, hasn't aged well IMHO)=--------PERSONAL GAME RESULTS-------=I give this game a 8/10I give this game a [LEGENDARY™ MOLE RAT STEW]

y 13, 2014
												Give the first game of this series a good try - even if it's surpassed by its more than splendid sequels. If you ignore a few annyoing bugs, some unfair battles and and the obsolete inventory/item management you'll experience an ~15 hours long trip like you've seldomly seen before in any other video game. Atmosphere, music, freedom of choices and the character development system stood the test of time and already cult - and even the isometric graphics have their very own charm.A tear of joy will definitely roll down your cheek when you finally defeat the obscure «Master» at the end of the game - how you do that is completely up to you.

content:
2, 2015
												Don't kid yourself, this game is OLD, almost ancient.You should probably only play this if you are a die hard Fallout fan or you're really into post apocalyptic isometric RPGs.You start off with almost no weapons from your Vault. Your mission: Find water. You only have a certain amount of "days" to do that (in game the time does not stand still). I don't know what happens if you fail, to be honest.You will have no one holding your hand in this game. No one. You have no quest log (as far as I can tell), you only find out what to do and where to go by talking to people (no, they do not have exclamation marks for quests). They give you missions, directions, intel, etc. These missions will have consequences. If you simply murder stuff or do shady deals and people find out, you get negative karma points and some people will be hostile. That being said, the choices you can make are rather nice, but can also screw you over. There are good walkthroughs out there if you want the optimal way to play, i.e. where to go, who to talk to and how to get the most XP and bottle caps.The latter are the game's currency. Although you do not strictly need them, because everything can be bought with everything. All items in the game have a certain value and you can simply trade them in. However, items also have a weight associated to them, so the bottle caps are definitely worth having. You can, of course, only carry so much (depends on your strength value). However, there is a trick, whereby your companion, which you can hire or not, can seemingly carry an unlimited amount of items. Of course he won't give them back to you for free, but you can steal it from them and they won't complain apparently.Your starting values and skills will be important and you can already mess up the game here. Every now and then you get a level up and can choose a new perk or upgrade one (not every levelup). You can also invest skill points into your various skills, from picking locks, to sneaking, conversation, healing or different combat traits. You can level a skill up to 100%. I would strongly suggest to invest into small arms initially, as most weapons, especially early on are in that category (from pistols to shotguns to rifles). And missing in this game can be your death.Combat is done turn based with action points and initiative. The values are often hard to gauge though. In any case you will usually have some sort of firearm and armor equipped. You can swap weapons mid combat, but it costs action points (AP). Everything costs AP. You can either fire your weapon unaimed, which costs less AP, or aimed. The latter allows you to target specific parts of your opponent. For example shooting and wounding the leg causes monsters to be slower (i.e. lose AP). Shooting the arms may cause opponents to miss more. Shooting the eyes give you a chance of blinding them. And a headshot can potentially do the most damage. Of course your hit percentage depends on your skill with a weapon type and the distance to the target. Funnily enough you can also fire your sniper rifle from point blank range. Generally speaking, the more damage a weapon does, the more AP it requires. You will also have to reload at times, which also costs AP and potentially your whole move. Some weapons also offer other modes of fire. Automatic weapons have a burst fire mode, which costs lots of AP and wastes lots of ammo and should only be used on close targets, but can kill targets quickly and also hurt other enemies nearby. Speaking of ammo. Every weapon in the game uses a different type of ammo, so try to specialise on 1 or 2 weapons, otherwise you will just be carrying around lots of additional ammo, which takes up weight.If you want to and find one you can also hire a companion...you should ♥♥♥♥ing do that. I can't imagine how to win the game without one. Tycho for example has loads of HPs and can fire almost any weapon. Be aware though that there is friendly fire in the game and the friendly AI cannot be controlled or given any orders. They will act on their own and they're ♥♥♥♥ing stupid, so don't stand in the way and try to keep them alive. It doens't help that you can't see their HPs...you can give the AI weapons and they will use whatever they deem best from their inventory.Movement and menus are a pain for modern days to be honest. Combat is "ok", but it just has this "feel" to it that makes it great somehow.Overall I like the game, though the story in general isn't very good imho. It's the individual people and missions that make this one entertaining.There is no difficulty setting I think, so I would urge you to read some guides on what to do and how to even play the game, because there is no tutorial.

content:
ry 2
The first game of the amazing series.

The story is about going out in an apocalyptic setting to find a "water chip" to replace in their vault.
Venturing off into the Wasteland that everyone is pretty fond of from playing the other Fallout games.
It's a very fun RPG game with the camera movement much like Diablo, although the controls are little more tedious with turn-based clicking combat.

A good game if you're a fan of older games and love Fallout.

7/10

												Thumbs Up!  Best Fallout Ever!  Look at those graphics.  OMGosh!  So Cool!;POk, really!  Why would anyone recommend this?  Well, for a blast from the past.  No mods!  No High Def!  Oh and some pretty tough game play (at least for me).  I picked it up simply for storyline and slight nostalgia.  Which is what I think most players picked it up for.  To complete the set and get that little bit of Lore you always wondered about.  Seriously, buy this game only if you want to experience the classics.  It's like buying Final Fantasy 1 cause you enjoyed 10 so much that you want to know the first game better.  It's a completely different beast but worth experiencing even if you never finish it. Or like playing Pac Man or Pong.  It's a classic worth trying.

ry 13, 2016
												This isn't a game, this Is an Experience. :DDon't buy it if you don't like reading, roleplay, using your brain, a challenge, or strategy. The combat really makes you think as opposed to just shooting randomly in big 3D open worlds where everything is a movie and holds your hand. There's no Autosave, sunshine. Welcome to the 90's. If you forget to hit that save button after defeating a horde of deathclaws and get shot a screen over by a bandit, tough Sh*t. Do it again.You'll learn to appreciate gameplay over graphics for once in your close minded life.Unlike the failure Fallout 4, (A blasphemy to the genre and series) there is more to the combat than just meets the eye.Chances are, if you're not a fan of dungeon crawlers, and whine about Nethack and the like as being "too hard" (Wah Wah you little baby) then go lower your IQ some more and buy the modern garbage they call video games and stop wasting your time on this classic.This game will wreck you, make you cry and then hug you and give you a cookie. It's not for the faint of heart, and neither is Real life when you think about it.If you think this review is too brutal, that's because this game twice as brutal.Fallout can change a man (but war, war never changes), I used to be as soft as a kitten before playing this harcore Sh*t. "Git Gud or Git Gud Not, there is no try."And you're gonna need to memorize these keyboard functions before you play, otherwise, expect carpal tunnel from all the clickin. So Get that pen and paper ready, grasshopper.:A - AttackC- Character screeI - InventoryP- pipboyZ - Pipboy clockHome- Center on PlayerS - Skilldex1 - Sneak2- Lockpick3- Steal4- Traps5- First Aid6- Doctor7- Science8- RepairB- Toggle active itemsN- Toggle item mode> - Rotate left< - Rotate rightF6- QuicksaveTAB- AutomapShift + Click - Run to designated location (Extremely helpful, no longer will my carpal tunnel act up from all the double clicks.)Enter - Ends Combat mode (if no enemies nearby)SPACE - Ends Combat turn

												This fantastic RPG has been in my Steam Library for some time now, and have posessed the desire to dive into it for quite a while. But only a few fays ago did I begin to play, and I have been hooked. So hooked in fact, that even when my save corrupted and set me back a few hours, I felt inclined to redo all that I had lost. I suppose it is feels just that fantastic to obliterate a base full of supermutants with a 40 shot burst minigun. For those who do not enjoy the turn-based style game, this is still highly recommended. It is a different style of combat compared to the modern first person Fallout titles, however it feels just as awesome and immersive to roam the wastelands and destroy the enemy. 10/10 Great GameP.S. Give the controls some time, you will come to understand and enjoy them.

content:
, 2013
												A very immsersive experience from back in the day, Fallout is everything  a role-playing game should be. You've got tons of options in how to customize your character, and can do practically anything. Someone insult you? Give em a bullet to the brain, a verbal smackdown, or a grenade in their pants! The plot is also well told, though requires some exploring to truly understand.All of this, however, is overshadowed by one unfortunate flaw: current computers cannot properly handle it. This leads to many graphical bugs that make it nearly impossible to play. Thankfully, many people on the internet and even here on Steam have come up with solutions. Look around for a mod called Fallout FIXT on the site No Mutants Allowed, and don't  afraid to ask for help!

content:
er 22, 2015
												To begin, I suppose I should say that I originally bought Fallout from Good Old Games, or GOG for short, long before buying that Fallout Anthology. With that said, I can assure you that I have more than the thirty minutes logged than Steam claims I do (at the time of writing).Now, where to begin...Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game came out September 30, 1997. At the time of writing, it's just over 18 years old, and still /very/ playable, provided you're willing to /deal/ with outdated graphics. For me, however, graphics have never been an issue, and even today, the sprites are not overly different than some Tactical Role Playing games, or some Turn Based Strategy games.Outside of the graphics, the game is similar to Fallout 3, and Fallout New Vegas. You're SPECIAL stats, along with your Skills, largely determine how you'll play. However, the main difference will be the lack of real time play.Onto the story, this is the game that started everything. Most of the series staples were implemented in this game.The Brotherhood of Steel, New California Republic, Followers of the Apocolypse, even Super Mutants and Ghouls all originate from this game. Never once did I think it was contrived. I genuinely enjoyed this game.

content:
3, 2014
												Things I Liked:Good StoryVery Strategy-Centric - hexagonal tiles mean that strategy is keyVariety in weaponsLore is really interestingThings I Didn't:More RTS-like than RPG, although RPG elements are thereThe graphics do not work on modern machines - many graphical glitches on my machineCombat is action point reliant - can be pretty dullGame mechanics are not very well explained - trial and errorOnce you die, you lose your character (may be a welcome challenge for some, but I am not a fan)No autosaves (adds to annoyance of above point)The Fallout series is well known by the gaming community, mainly for Fallout 3 and New Vegas but many have missed the first entry in the series, which can be picked up pretty cheaply on Steam.I had pretty low expectations for this game, being released in 1997 and all, but even so I was honestly disappointed from the get go, when I couldn't boot up the game, and when I did the opening cutscene wouldn't show without rainbows fizzing across my screen.Anyway, as I got into the game these glitches went away for the most part, and I could get onto playing the game, which was difficult without any clues on where to go or how quickly (you are given a time limit to complete the game, by the way). The storyline you follow is dull, although the background information is really interesting, with the end-of-the-world scenario that kicked it all off in pretty much every game since. be prepared though, this information is pretty much shoved in your face every time you talk to anyone. They respond to a two word question with a five hundered word essay, and you have to read it all to make sense of what's going on.The combat is what I thought the Fallout series would excel at, but I was wrong. enemies surround you far too quickly, you have to use 'action points' like a turn based strategy, in fact that's what the combat is, and I find it a hard concept to master.Overall this game is great for its story and lore but not so strong with its combat and mechanics in the modern era. Recommended if you can put up with the flaws of older titles.

content:
, 2016
												The controls aren't initially too bad, especially when you finally master them. Unfortunately, Black Isle Studios didn't have the knack to implement an abundance of voice actors. Truth be told there are only a handful of them in the entire game. Everything else is good old fashion dialogue. Sure, you might here me and other people complain about this. But let's just say, for the shake of this review. I get over the fact the game only has a limited amount of voice actors until Fallout 3. The only major problem I've encountered thus far with Fallout 1 through 2 (including Fallout Tactics) is the despicable combat system. I mean this combat system sucks.. I'm talking atari style combat.. A friendly individual fires first, then a hostile target fires second. It essentially goes back and fourth until one or the other is dead. This is extremely unrealistic, and truthfully. I don't believe there was any excuse for this whatsoever. Take my word for it, I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series; but this is just ridiculous. In closing this message, I want to add the story is of course outstanding. I hope one day they'll consider doing a remastered version of both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Preferably with Fallout 4's new creation engine.

content:
8, 2014
												This game is the beginning of my favourite series of games ever. I assumed that due to it's age and the companies behind it, that it would be pretty bad and boring, but I was very wrong. This game is full of a fair amount of quests that all have good story to them. The visuals are fine when the HD patch is applied. There is lack of audio in the game aside from the odd sound effect and combat related sounds such as gunshot. The game also has fairly slow paced gameplay and you'd have to be patient to deal with it at times. The game has turn-based combat using a targeting system called "V.A.T.S." that works on percentages. The games RPG elements are detailed with many perks and skills to train as well as using speech options that effect how the game plays out.If you're a fan of post-apocalyptic setting, don't mind the dated graphics and slow paced gameplay. This game is for you.12/15 - "Brilliant beginning to a brilliant series"

content:
7, 2014
												Fallout is a controversial came to me because there are many good and bad things about it. It can be genuinely fun, but you have to be willing to overlook a few problems. For one, non-violent character builds (i.e. focus on skills like sneak, speech, science, etc) are pretty much impossible to play for several reasons. A) There are random encounters in this game, which you will get constantly while fast traeveling. Unless you're really, really, lucky, you will get murdered by raiders and scorpions over and over again. B) You will miss out on XP through combat, which will make you way too low level. Secondly, most skills in this game are uneccessary or plainly useless. In order to have fun, I recomend you play the following character. Choose gifted and fast shot as traits, lockpick, science, and small guns as tag skills. Then go with 2 cha, 4 int, 4 str, 10 end, 10 agility, 10 per, and 5 luck. Trust me, just do it.It kind of feels like a let down in that you don't get a lot of freedom to do what you want. This game is very combat-oriented.  Another problem is the graphics. It personally didn't bother me, but I know it can upset some people. If that's important to you, maybe don't play it. Lastly, the game is arbitrarily hard. The first time I saw a mutant, I got blasted to bits in one hit. Make  sure to save often and I recomend playing on easy, because Fallout enemies are super unfair. However, don't let that stop you from enjoying it. There are many good things about it also. What I really enjoyed was the simple fact that no other franchise really makes post-apocalytpic RPGs. The enemies look all mad max style, how cool is that? The setting is really cool, and frankly, underused. I've always maintained that interesting settings *make* RPGs. The story of Fallout is actually pretty interesting, even if it is rather bare-bones. I was also really impressed by the goal of Fallout: you have only 150 days to get a water chip, which your vault needs. You're on your own and you have to figure out where it is quickly. It's almost like a sleuth or detective RPG. If you feel like the good outwieghs the bad, you should try it. It's not a perfect game and I probably wouldn't finish it gain, but it's a unique experience.

												I would say this game is for somebody who likes only running away so far when trying to escape a fight. I like the story behind that game but the last time I played I had just gotten out of the vault's canyon and then was killed by a radscorpian. I will play it again though... If you aren't used to the mechanics of top-down turn-based games like this, then that may be a little offputting when you're just starting. However, once you get past that, you are in for a very good game. The story is great. Having played the modern Fallout games previous to this one, I can say I wish all of them had as many dialogue chices as this. This game is a true RPG and I believe you should give it a try.

content:
, 2016
												Fallout is a classic Post-Apocalyptic role-playing game that took RPGing to a place other than medieval fantasy lands. It solidified the open-world genre with its highly interactive world and demonstrates an unusual amount of self-awareness.GAMEPLAY: 9/10Fallout is a game about choice. Every decision you make is acknowledged, either by scripted events or with the in-game Karma system. This game lets you do things that no other game would let you do. You can side with the main antagonist, kill children, or even complete the game without killing anybody. It's very big on the role-playing aspect and your stats matter. For example, playing as a character with low intelligence will reduce your character to a grunting idiot. It's not one of those fake RPGs where you just do the same thing over and over until you level up. In fact, grinding is pretty much absent since there are so many unique ways to gain XP. The combat system is decent but not the game's strong point. The game is full of well-written dialogue and complex conversation trees. There are many different paths to take which give the game incredible replay value. Overall, full of great non-linear gameplay. If the thought of not always knowing exactly what to do scares you, just view an online guide and you'll be fine.PRESENTATION: 7/10Fallout's graphics have aged much better than other games of the period due to using pre-rendered graphics. However, despite this, the game is still rather low-resolution and the UI is somewhat clunky. However, the sound design is excellent with great voice actors. The head models used when conversing with important characters are detailed and look pretty realistic for an old game. This game also game has excellent death animations that accurately reflect a weapon's kill power. However if you're squeamish you can change the settings to make it less gory or eliminate blood entirely. The CGI cutscenes also look great too. The music tops it all, however, with an excellent score composed by Mark Morgan.STORY: 10/10Fallout is an excellent example of combining gameplay and story. They are essentially the same thing in this game, as every action you take makes an impact on the plot. With loads of interesting characters Fallout will please fans of quality video game narratives.Overall this game is highly reccomended if you're a fan of intelligent and mature games. You don't need to be particularly intelligent to figure the game out, but you'll find you using your brain a lot more than other video games. A lot of people say it's just nostalgia, but the game was already over ten years old when I first played it, and I loved it. Definitely reccomended if you're a classic gamer or a fan of games that give you lots of choice.

content:
27, 2013
												[WARNING: Not a standard review, but rather a guide how to play old games when you first played newer ones, ie. Fallout 3 and New Vegas]This game came out in 1997, when I was only 2 years old. I doubt I was even self-aware back then.It won't be a surprise that I am much into newer games then. However, I like old games too, since I've been a player since I was 3 or so. However, I never had the pleasure to play any games from Fallout series until about, I guess, 2010 or 2011. The first game was Fallout 3 and the only thing that encouraged me to play this masterpiece (with flaws, bit still a masterpiece nonetheless) was the fact Bethesda Softworks made this, and I've been familiar with this company due to The Elder Scrolls. I was already a big fan of Morrowind and Oblivion back then, so I checked on (ie. downloaded it from torrents) Fallout 3, which was great, but also very black-and-white when it comes to story, moralities and taking sides.Then I checked out New Vegas. It was great, and I also noticed that it was more morally ambiguous than Fallout 3. There were much less obvious choices when it comes to what will come out of them next. I read some reviews on both games. Seemed like old veterans of Fallout series liked NV more due to it being more like previous games than Fallout 3. So I figured out that NV is somewhat like first two Fallouts, to some degree.In the meantime, while I was sucked into NV (after I bought legitimate versions of these games on Steam), I was trying to play older Fallouts (these were initially downloaded from torrents as well). Both first and second. I really tried, but couldn't do this because these games were... I don't know. Not outdated, definitely not. But definitely not as "user-friendly" as F3 and FNV. These newer Fallouts simply had more intuitive interfaces, prettier locations, simpler controls, beautiful and detailed environments and you could approach these games in many varying styles. Fallout is much more difficult, because you don't have autosaves, interface takes time to learn (especially exchanging equipment and trading), if you can do something, it is much less obvious, because it is a lot simpler to engage in straightforward combat rather than research how you can click on repair and/or sneak or science or whatever, and like Morrowind compared to Oblivion, much of combat isn't based on how skilled you are (ie. the player) at playing games and aiming, but on your character's skills and probability (ie. dice rolls). So it took me several approaches to both games (which took me several months) to try to figure these games out. I was constantly dying, I felt the pressure of time (150 days remaining before you can find the water chip for your Vault, jeez...). It was very hard to bear with.However, several days ago, original Fallouts were on sale. -75% off. Only 5€ for F1, F2 and FT. Would be a sin not to buy them. I bought them, despite the fact I knew it was very unlikely that I'd like them anyday soon.But you know, it's weird, because once you BUY something instead of getting it for free, you feel obliged to try it out even more. You feel like "for ♥♥♥♥'s sake, I paid money for it, so I MUST COMPLETE THIS GAME!".And I felt like that too. I still feel like that. It took me several months, but I ♥♥♥♥ING DID IT. I learned how to actually play this game!And I can wholeheartfully recommend it, but only if you know how it is like to play old games or if you are inhumanly persistent.

content:
0, 2015
												This game came out in 1997 and it surprisingly holds up to this day. I was afraid I wouldn't like it because of how old it was and that I had played Fallout 3 and New Vegas first but I was completely wrong. It's basically the same as Fallout 3 and NV but isometric. The classic Fallout charm is present in this game with a main story and a few side quests. Though the game seems kinda basic in some areas a lot of the game seems a lot deeper and more indepth than a lot of Modern RPG's. At the time I can imagine this was quite revolutionary setting the standard for RPG's in general.Only once or twice I got fustrated at the game, not due to the lack of direction but due to the logic I was using to solve a problem not working even though I felt like it should. However it turned out the thing I was doing you were actually meant to do later on but I originally didn't try it again until I looked up I was doing it correctly just in the wrong area. Oh well.As I mentioned earlier, the lack of direction is a big thing in this game. The first quest is "Find the water chip. Here is a place it MIGHT be." and that's it. It's very satisfying to complete quests because of this as you need to ask around and gather information to solve the quests for yourself.My only complaint with the game is that the combat is unforgiving and can be fustrating at times as you can get instakilled just because of a random critical hit. The accuracy is also unforgiving at times as well especially in skills that you haven' trained as much. It's not that it's stupid it's far too unforgiving for what it is.The bottom line:If you enjoyed the other Fallout games (including 3 and NV) you will like this one.

content:
y 28, 2016
												Fallout 1 is a very ♥♥♥♥ing good game. In fact, it's probably one of the best games of all time, and is definitely the best RPG ever made. Everything from the combat, which still holds up well today, to the dialogue, which is deep and satisfying with many options and even more outcomes, even to the ambient music, is perfect. Though the main allure here is the role-playing. Your stats actually matter (unlike the most recent FO games to an extent). In fact, early game your stats are the only thing that will keep you alive. If you chose wrong or without thinking, you're screwed. There are so many different outcomes to every quest and the game is very narrative-driven, but it still manages that feeling of complete player freedom that Bethesda have sacrificed so much to achieve in the newer games. Really, it's just ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Go buy it.

content:
31, 2015
												Skip Fallout 3, avoid it like the plague and cancer it is to gaming as a whole. Get Fallout 1, Fallout 2, and Fallout: New Vegas.This one is the most unforgiving of the three. You're on a time limit, certain dialogue options can completely destroy your reputation in some places, resulting in death or simply being unable to continue any further conversation. The atmosphere is great, so is the story. The writing is exceptional, but nowhere nearly as good as Fallout 2 and Fallout: New Vegas. Keep in mind that while the series has always prided itself in player choices, the game kind of feels linear at the start. In fact, the dialogue is so inconsitent that it almost feels like Skyrim. The combat system is also very comfy, just turn the combat speed up a bit so you don't have to sit there for 30 minutes and stare at some cave rat walk across the run while you're trying to run away from it.

content:
ry 25, 2015
												Not as good as the second game.  Much shorter (entire playthru doing everything except grinding random encounters for hours for most is around 20 hrs), and the whole timer thing puts a damper on things.  I play RPGs to avoid quick thinking.  I do that all day.  I like to think out my moves, and the turn based combat in this game allows that.  I like to explore.  I like to take forever to actually dent the main storyline quests.  The timer kills that quite a bit.  I get what they were doing, and that sense of dread was very real.  The writing is solid obviously, Black Isle duh.  I know what the timer was there for, and can appreciate the device it represents.  Any arguments for it are valid, but I am sure glad they took it out in FO2.  Other than that play this game.  If the graphics matter to you don't, also if you are impatient.  The UI is chunky, as it should be.  I actually like it, the whole pip boy novelty is solid.  It takes a few minutes in these games to shed off the expectation of convenience I get from the newer games today.  Not necessarily quest markers, or quest info even, but more ease of operation.  You gotta try things till they work in these games.  I like this.  Takes me  a few minutes to realize, but the wastelands are so harsh, even the game's ui fights you.  The hostility is palpable, and it is entirely worth it.  Who needs fast travel quest marker quests, banging out 5 at a time, when you could literally spend an hour pixel hunting, trying out different skills, talking to npcs, trying anything to avoid having to shoot up the place and make your life a ton harder.  All this just to get that one part you need, to trade for that other one part you need, so the guy who you are getting said part for will just give you bad information.  PLEASANTLY frustrating! :)

content:
8, 2016
												I want so bad to give this game a good review. I really do. I like this game, for the most part. But let's be honest here, it hasn't aged well at all. There is a lack of control over your other characters that is just horrible. There's a severe lack of balance in the way damage is delt. The way you interface with the game is probably my biggest problem, it makes the game practically unplayable. Everything is slow and delayed. I'm not recommending this game, don't misunderstand my intentions here. I'm not recommending the game because it's a good game, by 1997 standards. It's a classic, and it runs like a classic, that's been horribly neglected. This game really needs a remaster. A facelift and some adjustments to the controls, some minor adjustments to how your followers interact with you and you'll have something really great. As it stands though I just can't recommend it. It will be more frustration than fun. I do love the depth of the game, it's really great. And if it's on sale grab it, you might enjoy it, otherwise I think I'd look for something else. It pains me to hit the thumbs down button here but as it stands I feel this game provides more frustration than fun. I've spent more time waiting on screens to open and close and waiting on my items to switch than I have actually playing it. Here's hoping for that remaster.
