content:
12
												A classic in all regards I must say: gameplay, presentation, and story. Also when it comes to classics, however; an obtrusive control interface and mechanics that don't work in modern times. I've been a big fan of the Fallout franchise for at least 9 years at this point, my obsession starting with Fallout 3. A game that I believe still holds up quite well, same goes with New Vegas (the sort of actual sequel to Fallout 1 and 2). Although 3 and New Vegas have their problems, with their clunky combat system and more bugs than a cabbage field that hasn't been sprayed with pesticide, are what I classify as fun. Fallout 1, is not fun. As I mentioned earlier, it's controls are garbage and hard to get a hold of today and certainly was a niche for certain people back in day (I presume at least, I was born a year after the game came out.) Maybe I'm spoiled, I probably am, but the way you go about ANYTHING in Fallout 1 isn't intuitive in the slightest. Wanna check out that body? Right click mouse over the body, hold the left click down, and then move the mouse down to examine the body. Wanna hack a computer? Click on the red button at the far right of your interface and click "Science" and you'll get a yellow crosshair. Mouse the crosshair over the computer and HOPE you hack it. Hacking/lockpicking/any sort of skill check is asinine. You never get any indication of how tough a skillcheck will be unless you try to bash your head against it until you break the lock, get locked out of the computer, or magically it works. Combat I'm very split on. When you don't break your gun, drop your weapon, stab yourself, or miss, combat can be decent at times. Although even in a full suit of power armor, you can magically get one shotted by super mutants because...because. Fighting in enclosed locations is a hassle as well, since sometimes you can't see what position your enemy is at so sometimes your shot may be blocked so you have to use up precious action points to get an angle on them. Companions are also a detrement in combat, since they can miss and end up shooting you, getting a critical hit, and kill you. Thanks Ian. Other times they bug out if they run out of ammo, and ditch their gun. Even after giving them extra ammo, they never reverted back to their guns and only used a knife or just never ever fought any enemies ever again. I had to make 5 characters because each time I ran out of the very stupid time limit that's forced on you at the start of the game. Oh about that, this game is an semi-open world RPG with a TIME LIMIT. You have 150 days to get a water chip for your vault or else it's instant game over. 150 days sounds like a lot, but it really isn't. You'll use up those days trying to find a god damn piece of rope you need to travel down another vault to get said water chip. At least once you get the water chip, the time limit is gone. Looting is a pain if you're running with laser weaponry too, since you end up vaporizing your enemies who drop all their goodies on the ground. You have to individually mouse over items to pick them up, and sometimes items are so small, you miss them. I had to reload a save that was hours back, just to get a item I needed to complete the game with.tl;dr/wrap upFallout 1 can be fun at times. Most times however, it isn't fun at all. It's aged poorly, has a terrible interface, and has really dumb, easy to miss plot crucial items. It's neat to see where the series started, but I'd stick with any of the newer games.

er 18, 2013
												This is not like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. This game is tough especially for people who are not experienced in cRPGS. With that being said, this game is enjoyable- i clocked in about 25 hours. This game has many problems - bugs, broken and cut quests, outdated graphics(even with highrez mod), not fully fledged or connecting dialogue, outdated gameplay mechanics, having to optimize this game for your comp by yourself(THANKS STEAM...) and my main gripe that this game feels to me a beta for fallout 2 which most people say is the superior between the two.I feel this game gets the classic nod, because of what it brings to the western rpg genre  - a unique rpg system with perks, special stats and skills which affect the world around you, ambigous morality, interesting setting and lore, great story line, fairly good dialogue, random encounters.AS a person who's first fallout game was New Vegas, i felt really out of place when i first dl this game. Its really difference and theirs a learning curve to it.This game is old and outdated - this is true no argument about that. So it will affect my final score.My Score system: 10/10 is a perect, 5/10 is average, and 0/10 Horrible.This game is a 7/10, a good game. It should be played if your a fallout fan and have never touched this old cRPG classic.

er 21, 2015
												Well, at least I can tell myself that I tried. After hearing around the whole internet that this game was definetly better than Fallout 3 and on, I decided to buy it. I was sure that the game would have some pretty bad graphics and what not, but personally I don't mind old games and bad graphix at all. What a game should have, its value. A game with a good story, a good gameplay. and a good fluidity , it's a good game. Fallout 1 only gets the story characteristic right. Yes, the story is amaing, and t gets the feeling and atmosphere right. It was amazing to get inmersed into the wasteland for the first time, but, that's about it. Honestly, even modern Fallouts get this right. The problem with this game is the gameplay, and the pacing. My god.    The gameplay is horrible. It is so slow, and ridiclous, that it makes it boring. It's basicaly a point and click battle system, with enemies that deal ridiculous damage and never miss, while you are too weak and are constantly missing.   It never made me feel good, like an RPG usually does, about getting stronger with EXP., and then tackling the stronger enemies and achieving victories. Why? cause, and this is the best part, at the beginning of the game, you have a stupid time limit. You can't go around exploring the wasteland and getting stronger at your own pace! Nope. You need to hurry and finish part of the main quest with as little moves as possible, so you don't get a game over. If you are like me and you don't like looking up things at google to solve games, then you'll probably have to start over from scratch more than once to figure out what to do to solve this problem. It's just not fun. Anybody that likes this game is because they feel nostalgia. That's it. The game itsef is garbage, quite honestly. Every single character is shallow, except for the final boss, and the side-quest are crap. If you lived in the 80's and 90's this game would've been mind blowing. Today, it's crap.

content:
y 27, 2016
												The short version would be for you to get an upgraded experience from Fallout 2 and read about this one on the wikipedia or something.So this game has a lot of fan boys... This game suffers from serious gameplay drawbacks that make it more frustrating than fun. Like seriously I think a 5 year old could have designed better math models for the hit percentages in this game. Seriously, I had VATS 87% chance to hit then shoot and miss 18 times in a row. Guess what game... that's not an 87% chance. Now if this happened once or twice, ok that's one thing, but this is a constant fight the game puts you against for no reason.Next is the criticals... worst experience with them ever. After the first quarter of the game they will be the only enemy attack that will kill you. The normal attacks will hit you for 0 HP continuously, but then a mole rat will crit you for over 110 HP. The last boss is a perfect example of this. Him and his Super Mutants regular damage 0 HP lost, then a critical 200 HP lost. Your life will depend on a critical attack every turn of every encounter. Dreadul to a mathematical power of 50.Then there's a mixture of feelings when it comes to the stories and plot in the game. The NPC's are pretty deep and well planned out. They offer information on the world, and allow you to see a sort of cultural element to the Wasteland. I liked this alot, and the locations you do get to visit are unique and inspiring. Yet in the end they are far to sparse to really feel connected to. Then the map... oh god the map... You will waste most of your time traveling into areas that will never lead to anywhere. Then in a moment you will realize that 80% of the map is dead, worthless space. Thanks for wasting my time game walking through desert fighting mole rats for absolutely nothing.These combinations of bad gameplay make this a terrible game, but a great story. That's why I recommend reading on this one then moving to the second one. Nearly all of the problems in gameplay this faces are rectified in the second. Making Fallout 2 a much better choice for your money.

												Okay, no offense to people who like this game, but I can't stand Fallout 1. There are a lot of things that are just... bad. I don't like the combat, the movement system, the conversations, the artstyle, the HUD, the map system or the interaction system. Simply put, Fallout 1 may have been great for its time, and spawned a successful franchise, but it hasn't aged well. At all. Unless you knowthat you will absolutely love this game, don't buy it. Again, no offense to anyone that likes this game, but this is my take on the matter.
